Title: Hôtel très bien entretienu
Review: Un très bel hôtel, de grands bungalows à la décoration soignée, mais surtout un magnifique jardin très fleuri, avec un bassin aux nénuphars,...le tout très soigné, c'est bluffant ! le personnel est charmant. Un belle piscine avec une pataugeoire et un espace détente avec hamacs et vue sur le Mékong. L'endroit en soi est idyllique. Un nombre incalculable de vélos sont à la disposition des hôtes pour des balades aux alentours. Ceci dit, pour atteindre quoique ce soit (entre autres les rizières), il faut rouler sur 7 kms de nationale en vélo, et au Vietnam, c'est quelque chose !! Il faut slalomer entre les nuées de mobylettes, les camions qui font hurler leurs klaxons, les voitures....A ne pas faire avec des enfants en bas âge. L'hôtel propose des excursions sur le Mékong (un peu chères, mais sympas). On embarque les vélos sur le bateau et le guide de l'hôtel vous emmène en promenade sur des chemins moins fréquentés. A part ça, pas trop de choses à faire. L'endroit est vraiment pour ceux qui ne sont pas pressés et veulent buller un jour ou deux. Le moins reste la restauration. Petit déjeuner servi à table (certes, il y a tout ce que l'on désire, mais c'est toujours plus limité) et surtout, la carte du restaurant est assez limitée et les plats pas toujours à la hauteur. C'est dommage, car l'hôtel est tellement isolé qu'il est difficile de se restaurer ailleurs.

Title: Im Paradiesgarten
Review: Der Aufenthalt im Mango Home Riverside war wie ein schöner Traum. Das Resort befindet sich in einem grossen wunderschönen Garten. Hier gedeiht einfach alles: Sonnenblumen, Lotosblumen. Bananen, Papayas, Mangos, Mandarinen und noch viel mehr. Die Anlage wurde perfekt der Natur angepasst. Da ist der River, ein Seitenarm vom Mekong mit einmaligen Sonnenuntergängen. Man wird nicht müde die Schiffe zu beobachten die vorbeifahren und dann macht man selber eine Bootstour. Das Resort verfügt über viele gut ausgestattete, bequeme Boote. Wir buchten eine Halbtagestour mit der ausgezeichneten, perfekt englisch sprechenden Führerin Ha. Unser Zimmer,eine Suite war gross, gut eingerichtet und das offene Bad gefiel uns ebenfalls. Da ich mich an einem Morrgen unwohl fühlte, blieb ich im Bett und als das Zimmermädchen sah, dass es mir nicht gut ging, verliess sie schnell das Zimmer. Kam sofort zurück mit einen Gingerknolle, einem Küchenmesser und einem Beutel Schwarztee. Nun sprach sie auf mich ein. Ich verstand kein Wort, aber ich begriff, was sie machte. Sie schälte den Ginger, schnitt dünne Scheibchen ab, gab diese mit dem Teebeutel und etwas Zucker ins heisse Wasser. (Im Zimmer hatte es einen Wasserkocher). Dies musste ich nun trinken und dazu Gingersscheiben kauen und dann schlucken. Tatsächlich war mir nach einiger Zeit wieder wohl. Wir waren von fast allem begeistert - ausser dem Pool - der war sehr klein. Ein grosses Dankeschön an die herzlichen Angestellten, die uns umsorgten und verwöhnten.

Title: Excellent stay...

Title: Huye de todo lo supérfluo para dar todo el protagonismo al entorno.
Review: Buscando un lugar para relajarnos después de unos días en Saigon, nos decidimos por el Mango Home Riverside al leer las opiniones en TripAdvisor. Y sí, es cierto, el Mango Home Riverside tiene algo que enamora nada más llegar, o incluso antes, cuando te recogen en la carretera con el coche eléctrico para recorrer el pequeño trayecto entre cocoteros por el que sólo circulan los vecinos de la aldea a pie o en bicicleta. El Mango Hotel se encuentra en una zona nada turística. Es un lugar sin grandes lujos para dar todo el protagonismo a su ubicación, a la orilla del Mekong, y a las puestas de sol, que desaparece al otro lado del río. Así, Tanto el comedor como el sunset hall se orientan totalmente para permitir disfrutar al máximo del espectáculo de ver discurrir el río y las diversas embarcaciones que lo surcan, así como de los fantásticos ocasos, También desde la piscina, incluso desde dentro, puede contemplarse el río. La rodea un jardín de cocoteros, árboles frutales, un pequeño estanque con nenúfares... Realmente un pequeño paraíso. El personal es muy amable, y el hotel tiene bicicletas de uso agratuito a disposición de los huéspedes. Sin embargo, no todo es maravilloso en este pequeño hotel: las habitaciones son de un confort bastante limitado y muy poca gracia. Una vista agradable al jardín o una buena decoración mejorarían muchísimo. El cuarto de baño es inmenso y con una parte sin techo, con un jardín, y pese a esto, le falta mucha gracia también. Y tiene el problema de la "fauna" que puedes encontrar: ranas, gusanos de tierra... La limpieza de la habitación tampoco es una maravilla: había manchas en el suelo que se irían sólo con pasar la fregona. Pero uno de los dos días que estuvimos ni siquiera nos hicieron la limpieza. Otro punto débil del hotel es la restauración: el servicio es muy lento, y la comida no hace honor a la cocina vietnamita. La impresión que tuve es que intentan "occidentalizar los sabores (el propietario es canadiense) con lo cual se pierden parte de ellos. A favor, un excelente tour organizado por el mismo hotel, con el que, saliendo de allí mismo, descubrimos la zona por tierra y agua en 5 distintos medios de locomoción (barco a motor, canoa, bici, tuc tuc y a pie). Tuvimos la oportunidad de ver y aprender a hacer las galletas de arroz, elemento fundamental en la cocina vietnamita, en una casa particular, visitar una fábrica de ladrillos, una explotación de cocoteros, un lugar donde se fabrica licor de arroz. La mayor parte del recorrido se hace en el barco a motor, donde nos ofrecieron un coco a cada uno para beber, un montón de fruta que el guía peló y cortó para nosotros... un trato de reyes, en un barco excelentemente equipado incluso con tumbonas sólo para nosotros. Había incluso wc!! El recorrido en canoa por pequeños canales y en bicicleta me gustaron particularmente. En definitiva, Me encantó la esencia del hotel: disfrutar del paisaje y la naturaleza. Si mejora las instalaciones sin cambiar su esencia, será perfecto

Title: Room rates a 3; the experience was a 4
Review: The setting along the river is lovely and the gardens are beautiful. Our "garden view" room, however, was pretty basic - perhaps because you should be outside enjoying the grounds and not sitting in your room. The best part of the room was the bathroom, which was outdoors (but covered with high walls) - and almost as big as the sleeping room. The sleeping room lacked anywhere to open your suitcase, so we had to open them on the floor. The mattress was hard foam, but gave an OK sleep. The air-conditioner was a bit noisy. Staff were great. Almost everyone understood and spoke English - at least enough for us to get by - and they enjoyed the opportunity to practice speaking English with us. While the jug of mojitos was a bit watered down, it quenched our thirst and the bar was a great place to sit and watch the boats go by - ditto with the restaurant. Breakfast was not buffet, so we could order what we wanted to eat, which was good. The highlight was our trip with their guide on "Mango Cruise," where we got to glimpse local life on the waterways, visit coconut and brick factories, bike through the countryside, take a sampan down a canal, and generally have a great time. This is definitely worth a day or two - or maybe even more - and is an ideal getaway if you want a quick trip to the countryside from Ho Chi Minh City.

Set in lush tropical gardens, Mango Home is a place to relax and unwind. The food is delicious, the pool is warm, and you can sit and watch the boats all day long. Embrace the natural beauty, have a coconut, and listen to the birds. All of the staff are friendly, attentive and care about making your stay special. A wonderful place that you will remember forever.

Title: Fantastically relaxing hotel/resort
Review: Fantastic hotel/resort on the banks of a Mekong River tributary. The staff are exceptionally friendly and always trying to help. The room was huge, with an equally huge bathroom, that has a garden growing in it and a hole above in the roof. Very comfortable and air conditioned room (the bathroom is not air conditioned). Not, there may be geckos on the front of the cabin and perhaps spiders and other bugs. None posed any danger. Mosquito nets are available above the beds as well. The facilities are excellent, with a lovely pool, bikes to hire and a large lounge area facing the river. Breakfast is good, lunch and dinner is served until 8.30pm. The meals are fantastic. The staff even organised for a boat to take us across the the coconut factory on the other side of the river when we couldn't join a tour. Run by the same people who organise Mango Tours, but don't wait until you arrive to organise what you want to do. Check the website in advance and book your tour in advance, otherwise you may miss out like we did. They're very popular. All prices are quoted in USD, so they tend to be more expensive than other hotels. But you are paying for comfort, which you definitely get.

Title: UNIQUE, COMFORTABLE AND COMMENDABLE
Review: Stayed here 3 nights. Was looking for a peaceful land based escape in the Mekong Delta. Much of the Delta is heavily industrialised and other parts suffer from an excess of tours groups. Ben Tre Island seems, in most part, to be a happy exception to both scourges - and Mango Home is an excellent base from which to explore. Booked a "suite" at $50 a night. Value for money. Felt private. Room clean, spacious and with good amenities. Nice front porch, and funky part outdoor bathroom at the back. The restaurant/bar area has an excellent river view, even more so at sunset. Comfortable and chilled. Food and drinks are both good quality and served with a smile. Have read other TA reports bemoaning the price of meals. Sure, you can cycle down the lane 10 minutes and buy a bowl of noodles with tripe and liver, breathing in diesel fumes as the trucks honk their way past, and using google translate to understand your order (too late in my case). Or you can pay extra for comfy loungers and a sunset view with english speaking staff who try their best to serve you well (even if they don't always succeed). Choice is yours. But don't relate prices of the one to the other. It's like comparing apples and pears. Free bikes to use. Got lost for a day down avenues of coconut palms and leafy fruit laden lanes, with streams and rivers never far away. Special thanks to "Ben" in the restaurant for making me his special ginger tea and offering me a well tasty pho for breakfast, and to Jay for prompt and informative pre booking advice.

Title: Perfect!
Review: We really loved our two night stay here at the Mango Home Riverside. I would, hoverever, call it more of a Resort, than a Homestay or a B&B? The room had good AC, a mosquito net if needed and a really cute outdoor bathroom, as well as two different outdoor and covered sitting areas. The pool and riverside cabana, should, however absorb the majority of your lounge time, as both are first rate! The bicycles are plentiful, good quality and available for free at any time of the day. They have some boating excursions as well. We did the 4-6 pm sunset and turned out to be a private ride. The boat was equipped with chairs, lounge chairs and fruit. Pick up a Happy Hour Beer Bucket before you cast off and you will love be it! It almost seems superfluous to mention the extremely high level of customer service, but Mango even exceeded the high standards found throughout Vietnam. The eagerness and friendliness of all the staff is impressive, especially "Bun"! If you are looking to escape the city, relax and enjoy some leisurely activities (boat and bicycle) while seeing some authentic Vietnamese countryside, you will be rewarded with a stay here at the Mango.

Title: Peaceful place...food needs to improve
Review: We had a great stay here. The grounds are beautiful, the place as a whole is a good break from the hustle of HCM. Our kids had a lot of fun in the swimming pool. I also thought the staff had done a good job of making the bus connection from HCM seamless. Do note that the place is expensive - everything is quoted in USD. From the rooms to the restaurant prices. While the food is inherently inexpensive vs western standards, we are in the Mekong Delta, and the corner roadside restaurant that is about a 1km walk from the hotel offers amazing Bo Ko or Hiu Tieu for less than USD1.50 if you don't mind the lack of ambience and the noisy traffic. In the hotel, everything is at least USD5 and its fine if the food is good, but i found the food incredibly salty and the quantities were small. Breakfast was also very limited. Even USD50 boutique hotels offer elaborate spreads in the morning so I think MAngo could at least offer a simple pho in the morning as an option. So if not for the food, i'd give this place 4 stars.

Title: Relaxing place for tourists only looking for a resort
Review: The 2 of us stayed at Mango Home for 3 nights after travelling through Vietnam for almost a month. After reading some raving reviews, unfortunately I was a bit underwhelmed. Do let me start with the positives: it is located off the Ben Tre town in a quiet area on the riverside. The sunset lounge and 24-hour swimming pool make a very relaxing environment. The staff is friendly who always has 1 person who speaks descent amount of English. At the same time, there are certainly areas for improvement. For example, despite several reviews criticizing the lack of variety in breakfast, it remained an issue for us as well. (Giving you 4 options to choose how you like your eggs is not a variety!) The same items were served every morning and it'd be great if there was an option for Asian food as well. The food at the restaurant was descent but more pricey. The path from Mango to the main road was 700m where you could find local restaurants for much cheaper. But after sunset, the path became pitch dark and difficult to walk/cycle so we felt that it was safer/easier to eat at the hotel. We were given a map with bicycling routes. My boyfriend asked where we could see coconut processing factories and canals but was not given clear information by the staff. We stuck to the routes suggested but we were mainly biking on busy main roads and rice fields, which was not that impressive if you had seen rices terraces in other parts of Vietnam such as Sapa. Laundry costed $4 USD/kg and definitely the most we paid to have our clothes washed at a hotel in Vietnams. And not even ironing was done. Finally, I did not find it helpful to have all the prices listed in USD and not Dong. It is clear that they try to cater to tourists who prefer western comfort but i think using the local currency is just a normal part of travelling. Overall, it's a nice and comfortable place to relax overlooking the river. The value of what we paid for the room was very reasonable. But cost of food and laundry were big negatives. Plus you don't really see Ben Tre or have an authentic taste of the area by staying there.

Title: A great taste of the Mekong Delta
Review: Mango Home Riverside was a very nice place to relax and watch the river life go by. It's close to activities happening on the Mekong river and very quiet. A great bar/loung area to sit back with a drink. The staff were very friendly and helpful and the food was terrific. You can ride a bicycle around the local area and into the local market. Title: A lovely way to see true Vietnam
Review: We enjoyed our 2 day/1 night stay at the Mango Riverside as we really got to see life in Vietnam as it is today whilst enjoying wonderful hospitality. From the time we were met by our guide (Thanh) until we were dropped back to our transport back to Saigon, we had a wonderful time. Despite being drenched as it was raining when we were being driven in a tuk tuk to the sail boat, we had a great time as the tuk tuk wove through some narrow but green paths away from the township towards the harbour. Once onboard the boat, we were treated to fresh tropical fruits and bottled water as we sailed along the Mekong towards the Mango Home. It was a pleasant journey as we passed by fishing boats and factories which were situated along the banks of the Mekong. On arrival at the Mango home, we were shown to our room which was large and comfortable. Fresh fruit was again made available to us in the room. The bathroom was huge with an outdoor shower which we loved. There is no TV in the room but there are hammocks available as well as an outdoor seating for guests to enjoy the tranquility of the resort. Lunch was served in the one and only restaurant and the food was lovely (and plentiful). After lunch, we walked to visit a villager who makes rice paper and had a lovely chat with her husband after we all had an attempt at making rice paper). On our return back to the resort, we relaxed in the lounge area overlooking the Mekong before heading to the pool to relax and cool down. Dinner was a cooking lesson where we got to learn how to cook some Vietnamese dishes (with recipes provided on departure so you can try to recreate the dishes at home). Food was lovely once again. Drinks are not included our package and were a little on the pricey side (which was not a major issue for us). The beds were a bit hard but we had a good night sleep. There is a mosquito net as there are mosquitoes there given its location in the middle of a village along the Mekong. We were bitten but not badly and treated it as part of the overall experience. The next morning, after breakfast - which was a continental breakfast with eggs made to order, we were taken to the village centre to visit a bustling market, a temple, rice noodle factory with a sampan ride back to our boat. The morning tour ended with a visit to a coconut factory where we got to enjoy coconut candy, wine and banana wine (and more tropical fruit). Given the amount of food we had enjoyed that morning ,we chose to skip lunch to head back to Saigon early (to avoid the peak hour rush into Saigon) and were given little takeaway packs of food to enjoy on our trip home. We absolutely enjoyed our stay at the Mango Home and wished we could stay longer. A huge shout out to our guide during our stay (Thanh) and our boat captain. They were friendly and hospitable and looked after us very well (especially me as I had injured my ankle at the start of our trip to Vietnam so needed to take extra precautions when getting on and off the boat and walking). We are looking forward to our return visit back to the Mango Home.

Title: Très décevant
Review: Cet hôtel était une étape dans notre tour du Vietnam (circuit privé). Situation en bord de fleuve, à l'écart de la ville, au calme (si on excepte les moteurs des bateaux, jour et nuit...). Entretien des abords approximatif, et chambre franchement sale, surtout la salle de bains (nombreux insectes sur les murs, sol sale). Chambres bien décorées, mais peu fonctionnelles, toutes alignées de plain-pied, avec entrée sur le jardin. La salle de bains manque d'équipements pour poser ses affaires, et le bac à douche avec rideau (trop court) fait bien sommaire. Les volets sont fixés aux vitres, ce qui fait que vous êtes dans le noir si vous voulez faire fonctionner la clim sans ouvrir les fenêtres. Sans clim, chaleur étouffante (décembre). Insectes et lézard dans la chambre pour la nuit ! Frigo (bruyant la nuit, et pas dégivré depuis des lustres), corbeille de fruits, bouilloire avec thé et café, bouteilles d'eau à disposition. On est bien reçu, avec rafraîchissement et tour du domaine, puis le personnel disparaît. On les entend bien rire et se détendre, mais personne ne s'active (alors qu'un coup de balai à la terrasse n'aurait pas fait de mal et que des bouteilles vides traînaient dans les allées). Il faut chercher si on a besoin de quelque chose... Cuisine curieusement très éloignée du restaurant en plein air. Espace détente bien aménagé et agréable (avec wifi) au bord du fleuve avec tables basses et fauteuils, où nous avons passé le plus gros de notre temps libre. Title: Comfortable, clean and well-maintained small riverside resort
Review: Due to travelling along a large section of the Mekong in a short time, we only stayed at the Mango Home Riverside for one night before moving on, but we found the small resort (I'm not really convinced that "homestay" is an accurate term?) to be very comfortable and a very nice introduction to Mekong riverside accommodation. To start with, our hotel transfer from HCMC was well-arranged and comfortable, with a couple of very special boat rides and walking tours on our way to the resort prior and post check in (Optional Separate Extra through Mango Tours). Our Suite Room was comfortable, with a decent bed, basic storage & furnishings (minibar), and a full outdoor bathroom to the rear (large bath, vanity basin, open WC and shower head). It gives the opportunity to see some of the local wildlife from your shower (!!), but it is covered and water pressure/heat etc is fine. The room itself is traditionally furnished but clean and very quiet, and possible to keep "pest free" for the night with a few towels on the ground below the doors. There is also an adjoining outside relaxation area for daytime reading of books etc should you have time. The resort grounds are well maintained but quite uneventful, and unfortunately dont really leave much of a view across the river itself (we parked on the end of one of the hotel boats at the hotel pier to take in the river sights). Given the location, we gather that dining options are essentially limited to the resort kitchen, but we found the dinner options to be adequate and of a reasonable standard. The staff are all very friendly and willing to help, and seem to take pride in the upkeep of the property and their guests happiness and general "Mekong Experience". In general we were actually pleasantly surprised as we are NOT normally "homestay" or "B&B" accommodation users, but we found that the Mango offers very comfortable, clean and pleasant accommodation for a short stay whilst on the Mekong.

Title: Excellent in many ways, lukewarm in others
Review: Before booking at Mango, I read the many rave reviews on this site. While I cannot disagree with any of them, most seem to be written by people on their first tour of Vietnam, so they sound a little starstruck. Let me add some depth from someone who has travelled extensively in SE Asia. First of all...if the word 'home stay' conjures up visions of being at someone's home, seeing how they live, etc...that's not what it means here. Mango Homestay is merely a small resort on the banks of the Mekong, way out of town. The rooms are very nice and the decor is exotic, but less than, say, a nice Thai resort. There is a very nice central building where meals are served (a bit pricy by VN standards, but quite affordable by North American standards. Expect appetizers to be about $3, main dishes to be around $5-8, beers at $1.75). This is about twice what these things cost in most restaurants, so if you are someone who likes a 'good deal', it might bug you a bit. The food is quite nice, but not really exotic. Lots of deep fried things. When we arrived, it was the heat of the day and everyone siestas. However, the resort only has 3 hammocks, so all the best siesta places (hammocks and couches) were occupied by the staff! It felt very uncomfortable to ask them to move, so I sat in a less comfortable spot until the heat passed. They really ought to have hammocks everywhere. Be aware also that, while the buildings are very well maintained and lovely, the grounds feel a bit overgrown and unkempt. Many resorts have manicured lawns with paths and sitting areas, but that's not the case here. So you don't spend much time strolling the grounds. Lastly, you pay for everything except the welcome fruit basket (4 bananas) and the two small bottles of water. All your snacks, bicycle rentals, scooter rentals, meals, beers...everything is priced in US dollars (red flag) and you are pretty much a captive audience. Again, prices are low by US standards, but not by Vietnam standards. Some extras, like the half-day river cruise, is actually a bit dear. But it's also very nice...your call. So enjoy the tranquility, the lovely rooms, the fantastically friendly staff and pretty good food...but if you're at all budget conscious, you'll find yourself just hanging out being a bit over cautious about costs. My recommendation: plan on spending $50 a day on extras (a fortune in Vietnam) and treat yourself.

Upon our arrival we were greeted by Jan who to our delight had upgraded us to their deluxe suite! Lucky us as they have substantial private outdoor seating, a lovely outdoor bathroom with shower/tub. Clean, comfortable and good sized bedroom with AC if needed. This lovely quiet spot is accessed by being picked up on motorbikes and whisked to this riverside oasis. There are plans for a pool for next season which would make it the perfect place for a quiet few days and an added bonus they really need. There is little else to do but relax or go out touring on the bikes they have available. Our breakfast was more than adequate although other meals not so impressive. Our main reason for staying here as well was to partake in the Mango Cruise which is also owned and operated by the same people. We were fortunate to have two lovely German gal's join us for the day and Dru (our guide who I hope I spelled his name correctly!) was amazing. We spent a good day exploring the area in the company Sampan which is exactly as it looks online!! We visited a brick, then coconut factory, had a paddle down a canal with two Vietnamese ladies, enjoyed a family visit tried making rice wraps and visited with a former Viet that fought in Cambodia. We did not see ONE other tourist throughout this very interesting and informative day. Cons: There are only two things that I wanted to mention in the cons 1) the evening meals were not that great - it might behoove them to perhaps add a few more items to the menu. Banh Mi/Pho. 2) I was a little disappointed that they charged for use of the bikes the charge wasn't much but I'd prefer that they included it in their services. Understandably there is a cost to maintaining them so I presume that's the logic. Big cudos' to the staff - in particular Jan and Dru who went out of his way to help us get some medication from the local pharmacy after he had finished his day of being our guide!!

Title: Site pittoresque, reposant : le paradis
Review: J'ai résidé à Mango Home Riverside comme voyageur individuel ne faisant pas partie d'un tour ou voyage organisé. SITUATION : Quand vous êtes au centre ville de Ben Tre, prenez la direction de My Thanh, sortez de la ville, roulez quelques km, franchissez le pont et 200 m après, à hauteur d'une gargote appelée "Muoi Chau pho", tournez à droite sur un petit chemin cimenté accessible uniquement aux 2 roues. A l'unique intersection, prenez à droite et allez jusqu'au bout du chemin où se trouve l'hôtel. Il est construit au bord d'un bras du fleuve, dans un écrin de verdure, loin de la route. Pas facile à trouver mais quelle récompense pour ceux qui recherchent le calme. C'est un grand jardin tropical au milieu duquel se trouve le restaurant, une terrasse couverte qui accueille notamment les participants des excursions en bateau proposées par Mango Cruises et une aile regroupant les chambres. Le débarcadère est aménagé avec de confortables fauteuils sous une tonnelle, lieu idéal pour observer la vie sur le fleuve. ACCUEIL : Les informations fournies par Mango lors de ma réservation étaient utiles. Le personnel parle très bien anglais, est courtois et serviable. CHAMBRE : Belle chambre propre à la décoration simple et agréable. Climatisation, minibar, bouilloire avec thé et café, corbeille de fruits frais. A noter qu'il n'y a pas de coffre. Le lit dispose d'une moustiquaire, la literie est de qualité. L'extérieur de la chambre est aménagé avec canapé de jardin et petite table, parfait pour profiter du jardin. Le soir, on s'endort bercer par le chant des insectes et le léger ronronnement des quelques bateaux de passage, un pur bonheur ! Shampooing, gel douche et savon de qualité sont fournis. Seul bémol : la douche dont le bac n'est pas assez profond ni le rideau assez long pour empêcher les éclaboussures. Même en faisant attention, la salle de bain était inondée à chaque fois. Suggestion d'amélioration : mettre une cabine de douche avec panneau en verre. PETIT DEJEUNER : composé de fruits frais, d'œufs, pain, boisson chaude et jus de fruit chimique, dommage... SERVICES : wifi qui fonctionne même dans la chambre la plus éloignée - prêt de vélos indispensables pour découvrir la région et moyen de locomotion idéal - laverie, tarif au kg de linge - réservation de billet de bus - excursions en bateau - restauration sur place, cadre agréable et cuisine délicieuse - cours de cuisine Je recommande vivement ce havre de paix pour les personnes recherchant le calme et souhaitant découvrir la région à vélo ou en bateau. Mango possède de jolis sampans, voir sur leur site, les excursions proposées car je n'ai pas testé.

Title: Authentic experience in Vietnam countryside
Review: We stayed at Mango Homestay as the second stop on our 7 week Vietnam trip. After 5 days in Saigon we really appreciated the peaceful setting of of this hotel. We took the bus from Saigon, we hadn't reserved ahead but when we got to to the bus station the ticket agent knew exactly where we were going and arranged our free minibus transfer as well. After being dropped off by the minibus on the path to the hotel, we chose to just walk in, it was a beautiful walk and only took about 10 minutes. The main attraction for us of this hotel was the setting. Not only are the hotel and grounds beautiful, the surrounding area is residential, in an arrangement that is very unusual to a North American. After leaving the main road, you follow concrete paths that are accessible only by scooter, bicycle or walking. Small plots of land along the paths contain houses, small farms and small commercial operations such as production of rice paper and noodles, coconuts or mangos. You see many people outside of their homes, and they are so friendly, always a big smile and usually a "Hello". I never felt when walking outside of the hotel grounds that I was intruding. We had the same experience when exploring further by bike. My husband and I had a hard time following the map provided by the hotel, but we loved every minute of our cycling adventures. A special treat was when met children bicycling home from school, they seemed delighted to see us on our bikes and always greeted us with cheery hellos. Regarding the hotel, we had one of the larger rooms with partially open air (connected) bathroom. The room also had a private sitting area outside with hammock. The room and especially the bathroom were very well equipped and we had everything we needed to be very comfortable, including a bathtub, it was a great experience to soak in the tub and feel the open air. The air-conditioning and wi-fi worked beautifully. We ate all our meals in the restaurant for two days, the food was excellent and it was a good opportunity to sample some Vietnamese dishes that we hadn't tried yet. We did the half day tour and it was well worthwhile. It included very interesting tours of small local industries (coconut processing, brick making, rice paper making). Also a short bike ride and a trip on a small boat down a beautiful narrow stream surrounded by coconut trees. Sharing the tour was also a great opportunity to get to know the other guests at the hotel. The staff at the hotel were very friendly and helpful. I would recommend this hotel to anyone looking for an authentic Vietnam experience, without having to sacrifice any comforts. I think it is a good example of how tourism can co-exist without any negative impact on the local residents that I could see. The hotel seems to naturally blend in with the surrounding area.

Title: A riverside idyll
Review: I stayed at Mango (actually called Mango Home Riverside) for two nights and had a brilliant time. I contacted them directly to book, and Mr Man was extremely helpful. He even upgraded me to the higher level of room as the one I wanted was only available for one of the two nights, and the more expensive room was out of my price range. He also gave great directions for getting there from Saigon (I have pasted these below). The staff throughout my stay were brilliant - really friendly and helpful. The room was fantastic and I loved the outdoor bathroom. The setting is idyllic - the gardens and the view over the river from the pier, especially at sunset, are just stunning. I hired a bike and used Mango's hand drawn map to cycle round the local countryside and villages, which I think was the best day of my trip so far! If you do this, the nearest temple on the map is definitely worth stopping at for a quick look around. It's also useful to get a map loaded on your phone when you're out and use GPS to see where you are if you want to take the long way round to Ben Tre, as this bit is not properly marked on the paper map and there are no clear signs! The only downside for me was that I found the food and drinks a little pricey - especially the water (they only sell small bottles, for $1.25). However, this was a splurge for me as I'm used to staying in much more basic accommodation, so I suppose that's to be expected. I had to search for a long time to find direct contact details for Mango - you can use , +84 96 7683 366 / +84 753 511 958 . Overall - thoroughly recommended. Directions from Saigon: In Saigon make your way to the Minh Tam Bus Station - 204C Su Van Hanh Street, District 5. (Opposite to the April 30 Hospital and near the Windsor Hotel). Vietnamese Translation for your Taxi in Saigon: VUI LÒNG ĐƯA TÔI TỚI SỐ 204C SƯ VẠN HẠNH QUẬN 5 ĐỐI DIỆN BỆNH VIỆN 30/4 You will take the bus to the Minh Tam station in Ben Tre. Minh Tam Bus can then arrange a charter (free of charge) for you to the village road at Mango Home. They then use their shuttle to drop you off at "Pho Muoi Chau" Muoi Chau Noodle shop. From there you walk 10 minutes through the village path to Mango Home Riverside. Vietnamese Translation for the staff at Minh Tam Station in Ben Tre: Vui lòng đưa tôi đến cầu kênh CHẸT SẬY bên kia cầu quán phở MƯỜI CHÂU. Tôi đến công ty DU THUYỀN XOÀI

Yes, it is a little pricier than most things in Vietnam, but the memories of the attention to detail, the quality, the avoidance of the dreaded tourist hordes will be with you for a long time. We felt fortunate to have experienced part of the Mekong Delta in this manner.

Title: A thanks and a gentle prod!
Review: Mango Home is a place with amazing promise and loads of potential. Its promise is the possibility of a quiet relaxing break from the madness. Its potential, as this area opens up to tourism, is to be the first and best at it. This small resort is a fairly new venture in a distinctly un-touristy area in the delta and in prime position to take advantage as the area develops. The absolute stars of the place are the manager Man and his staff. Man is affable and very much a hands on guy and the staff all equally personable and willing. The food is extremely good, and of note is the individually decorated plates with leaves and carved fruit and veg. One of Mans personal contributions I believe.The menu is perhaps a little sparse for choice, especially if you are used to a western diet but the Vietnamese dishes, particularly the fish, are lovely. I netted and bought fresh live King Prawns at the local market and Man, a fine cook, personally prepared them for me to my requirement. A real plus! Something has to be said regards to the mode of transport into the resort from the main road. This is by small motorcycle and I can fully understand why this may be a frightening experience for some. Now! I am an accomplished motorcyclist having ridden large bikes such as my Harley for many many years, fifty to be precise, and I absolutely detest being a passenger on the rear and would never dream of doing so in the “real” world. I live in Asia and witness the suicidal antics of small bike riders daily and have no wish to become a statistic. I suggest arrival by boat for sanity. Also, unlike previous reviewers, we did not find the resort as quiet as we had hoped. In a Vietnamese context it is, I suppose, quiet. In a South East Asian context where they are familiar with tourist needs, not so much and in an International context, not at all... The staff had a tendency to congregate in the vicinity of our room, and where you have three Asians talking together it sounds like a party, when you have eight it sounds like a football match. This, I know, is a cultural phenomenon as I have lived in the region for years. Asians and Asia are simply loud, this is a given, just the way it is. but it does not help when they are sitting at a table directly at your bedroom window on the adjacent, contiguous terrace. Quality Resorts that have been at it for a long time know this and have strict rules for their staff. Small motorcycles running early in the morning beside the room is also not a good idea. Further, roosters squawking and dogs barking may be quaint and rustic in this rural setting during the day but at five in the morning, perhaps not so charming for many. This was exacerbated by workmen renovating the external rooms in the compound. If we had known this we would have arranged to come on a different date. If it is to be a quiet place to relax and chill, then it must, BE, quiet! I really hope that these issues are dealt with as I would dearly love to be able to return.

Title: Glad that's behind me!!!!!
Review: I wholeheartedly agree with the top contributors review below jroihi on ALL the issues raised. Mango is not the easiest place to find it is several hundred meters from the main road only accessible by bike or foot. Something Agoda or Mango fail to mention in their description. It is in a beautiful spot but you are completely isolated. Walking at night is not an option between the falling coconuts and neighbourhood dogs, (some in packs) protecting their territory you are stuck. Mind you there is nothing else in the area anyway which is a huge advantage for Mango as you are completely reliant on them for all your needs and they know it. We booked two nights, planning to go on a mango cruise but due to terrible weather conditions had to cancel. I can accept the remoteness of the B&B and frankly quite like travelling off the beaten track but it’s what followed that really made my blood boil. On the first evening the owner told us they had a set menu option for dinner which sounded very nice the price US$10 per person. The food was well presented but that’s where it ended the portions sizes were ridicules, after spending 4 months in Asia I am used to small portions but this was absolutely outrageous i.e. the chicken curry had 5 small pieces of chicken this portion was supposed to be shared between 3 adults. A blatant rip off I am really surprised no one has mentioned this before but looking back at passed reviews I understand now why they are few and far between. The next evening we order off the menu I had chicken curry again and this time I had 4 pieces of chicken all to myself! I would have gone out for a meal on the 2nd night but as I said above it wasn’t possible. A standard bottle of wine was priced at $40 the most expensive standard wine we encountered on our 8 weeks in Vietnam On arrival I noticed that the menu was divided into two currencies some items were priced in US$ and others in Dong I immediately told my partner this is going to be an issue when paying the bill and it was. On requesting the final bill it was given to us in Dong the items priced on the menu in US$ had been converted in to dong at a rate which was not correct. When my partner went to settle the bill the Dong bill was then converted into dollars at yet another false rate ( I think they just make it up as they go along or depending on the person) and then they wanted to convert it back to dong using yet another rate all these conversions. The bill was already in Dong so why convert to $ then back to dong simple answer they want to make money on the exchange rates by doing this they also confuse you. My partner refused he insisted that he would pay the bill in dollars even though it was not the correct rate. I was furious and would have complained, but I did understand his point we are in the middle of nowhere how would we manage to get back to the road or out of the area if they refused to take us. Later when I worked it out we had lost around 18 dollars I know that’s not much but I guess they are relying on that way of thinking. If he had allowed them to convert back to dong I wonder how much we would have lost then!! I could go on & on like having to change rooms the next morning with some silly excuse etc…. but I think the reviewer below pretty much covered the rest. You have been warned!!!!

Title: Fab place...
Review: We found the Mango Homestay via Trip Advisor and were certainly not disappointed. The house and terrace is set in a garden filled with butterflies on the banks of the Mekong River with its own private jetty where you embark on the boat for your tour (which you must do, trust me). The staff are delightful (Mr Man in particular), the food is delicious and freshly cooked) and the rooms were spotlessly clean and air conditioned - the outside bathroom and shower is particular fun. We stayed for two nights and LOVED it. However, having read the last negative review I would add the following note. This is NOT a luxury hotel and coach trip - this is Vietnam and it's a homestay - a delightful one with a bit of adventure. It is a two hour bus journey from HCMC with a five minute car transfer after that and then a five minute back of motorbike ride for the last half mile down paths through the local hamlet as Mango is not accessible by car. It's remote but that makes it even more delightful. It may seem chaotic but it's actually all very well organised (and that's a metaphor for most of this wonderful country)- take a taxi to the Minh Tam bus company in HCMC (tell them you're going to Ben Tre and Mango) - they get you off at the right stop and then drive you on by car to the transfer point where you're met by Mango stiff on motorbike. Travel light, go with the flow and you'll have a fantastic experience.

Title: A Very Unpleasant Surprise
Review: Whenever I write a negative review I suggest that readers read all of the reviews and form their own opinion. I have thought several days before writing this because it is still hard for me to believe and I continue to ask, “How did we not know?”. We are in our 70's and this was to be the relaxing culmination of a month long trip to Thailand, Cambodia, and Vietnam. I had had extensive email conversations with Jay and was really looking forward to the wonderful sounding stay at Mango and very special day tour at the end of this amazing but exhausting trip. WE knew we would be picked up by private car in HCMC and taken to Mango Homestay and the pictures were so inviting. The ride there was pleasant until our driver suddenly with no communication (He didn't speak English but this “process” should have been explained before) pulled to the side of the road, empty except for one of those little huts that sell drinks. We had no idea why he was stopping but then he opened our doors and went to the back and quickly took our bags out. We had no idea where we were or what was happening. This was not Mango. Just a dusty stretch of road! I panicked I climbed out of the van as there was nothing else to do as our luggage was now at the side of the road. Then I turned and a motorbike was directly in front of me and I was told to “get on!”.. No explanation. Where was Mango? I had never ridden a motorbike and hadn't planned to begin at 75. I didn't know where to put my feet or where to hold on, so with discomfort, I put my arms around the waist of the driver. We started down a narrow path with many sharply tilted turns. How long would this be and HOW could it be? By that time I was traumatized. Not knowing where we were going or how long this ride would be and trying to protect my back from the hard bounces, we finally arrived at Mango. That is a blur to me. I arrived at our room in shock. trying to process what had happened.. I was shaken and my husband was confused. Our room, which was next to the kitchen, had no table or any chair and no private patio. One of the dining area tables was directly outside our window. Apparently “private” as used in the descriptions means for use of all guests only. No TV which was ok except it said there was one.. The bed was in front of the window and it was the only place to sit so unless you stood at the foot of the bed there was no view. We ate in our room using a footstool that was brought in for a table and sat on the end of the bed. The food was indeed well prepared as others have described. I was shaken and did not sleep well. Even if the description at booking dot com had not mentioned that on site parking was available, I had no reason not to expect to arrive at that wonderful scene in the picture. I don’t understand why no one else has mentioned the need to enter by motor bike nor do I understand why Mango does not explain this in their literature or why it was not mentioned in my extensive conversations with Jay. I'm sure for younger folk, that could be part of the adventure but at 75 it was very frightening and awkward. Had we known this was the only way in we would not have stayed there. The next morning we canceled our tour partly because we wondered with all the changes in vehicles what other unpleasant surprises might face us. We had arranged an option instead of the bicycle but now we could not be sure if that was our only obstacle on the tour. Rather than the motorbike we took 20 minutes to walk out to the road. Jay and I had exchanged many emails and I thought coming to Mango would feel like coming home. He had arranged for us not to use bikes on the tour so he certainly knew we had limitations. I never dreamed I would be writing this kind of review, I do think Mango needs to give a more accurate description of the arrival process, the rooms, and the parking situation. For those not our age and not disturbed by the arrival process, this could be a wonderful time I am sure, but for us it turned into a nightmare. and we lost our only time set aside for a river cruise. Any trip of a month will surely have its unpleasant surprises but I never thought it would be this. I know many have had wonderful stays here but this is my experience and that is what TA is for.

Title: Exactly What We Wanted
Review: I think this is my first tripadvisor review but we are having such a great time that I feel I have to share our experience. All we really understood was that we had a arranged a two night/three day tour of the Mekong Delta but what Mango delivered was something much, much better. I'm typing this from the front porch of their lodge looking out over the river, watching the boats, many loaded with coconuts go by, watching the sun set after a really brilliant day of activities. Frankly its a bit hard to convey but basically they offer what I can only describe as an beautifully choreographed peek into rural life. How shall I say...the gain without the pain. Here is how it went. After getting up very early this morning my wife, my two boy's ages 11 and 13 and myself started the day with a boat ride to the floating market. But what was really special happened next. After a three hour car ride we made our way to a group of three island that are unique in that they don't have any cars and so Mango had set up a series of little events one after the other in which we first walked through the orchards, then went by boat to see brick making, then small cart to see noodle making, dugout boats through narrow channels, to another boat and then to the resort itself. The kids loved it. Each event (and I'm sure I've left out half of them) was just the sort of thing kids really get into. And each was just the right length. Enough time to not feel rushed (we could also adjust set the pace because it was only us) and then off to the next thing via a short walk or ride. But the best were the "surprises." I hate to spoil the effect but here is the part that makes it all work. Just when you think you have walked just the right amount (remember its hot here) you round a corner and...there's a boat. A very nice traditional boat, with cold towels, cool drinks, shade and cross breeze to whisk off to the next part of your adventure. With all the development this is a great (and extremely pleasant) way to peek into a bit of rural life as it was in way that you couldn't possibly put together yourself. I'd highly recommend it for families especially if you have kids that like seeing how people live and things work.

Title: Beautiful Garden Retreat
Review: We really enjoyed our 2 night stay at Mekong Home. We were there during rainy season and initial impressions were poor from the road as we waited for a porter to assist with luggage. The walk down the long path in rain dodging puddles and rubbish was not a great start. But once we arrived at MH our attitudes took an immediate turnaround. The tropical style gardens, pool and pavilions are gorgeous. It felt so peaceful. We were welcomed by the the Khoa the manager and shown to our very stylish bungalow rooms. Beds were very comfortable, air con fantastic and the room spacious. Breakfast and dinners were all very tasty and we loved the foot bath after dinner on our second night. The kitchen staff were very friendly and smiling. I would suggest that they await guests arrival to the pavilion before cooking as some food were cold but were happily reheated by staff. We took the morning boat tour and were lucky with the weather. Our guide had great English and we really enjoyed all stops. We saw coconuts being processed, brooms being woven and finished with being rowed along a arroyo. Khoa was happy to organise other tours around the area if required. His overall management of all guests at all times was impressive to watch. It was clear he would do everything in his power to ensure guests had the best time possible. The hotel is a fair way out of Ben Tre but as this was towards the end of our month long trip we were very happy to relax in the gorgeous surroundings and enjoy the pool. I would totally recommend to others as a good choice for some downtime especially when weather makes other parts of Vietnam not such a good location. Especially as its not that far from HCMC. There was a lack of hot water in the shower but as others have mentioned this is due to the use of solar panels and was something we encountered at every property we stayed at the Mekong Delta and other parts of Vietnam as well. We thought the pricing here was very reasonable for the standard provided and would definitely return.

Title: Un'oasi in cui sostare per esplorare con tranquillità il magnifico territorio del Delta del Mekong
Review: Leggendo di questo posto prima di partire me ne ero già innamorata, tanto da escludere tour “preconfezionati” sul Mekong perché oltre ad essere estremamente turistici non ci avrebbero consentito di pernottare qui.....Una volta arrivati è stato bello trovare esattamente quello che mi aspettavo! La struttura si compone di una serie di bungalow, ben distribuiti all'interno di un giardino lussureggiante molto curato, con piante locali. Dal giardino si accede al ristorante all'aperto e anche ad un pontile con sdraio, dove la brezza regala un piacevolissimo rifugio dalla calura garantendo assoluto relax! La nostra camera era molto spaziosa e caratteristica, con un’ampia vetrata sul giardino; sul letto avevamo una bella zanzariera di tulle bianco per garantire sonni sereni (all’arrivo avevamo visto svolazzare qualche zanzara nel bagno ma in realtà non ne siamo stati mai infastiditi). Ci sono sia aria condizionata (ben funzionante!) sia ventilatore. La colazione (e, volendo, anche i pasti: light lunch a 100000dong - poco meno di 4€- e ottima cena a 200000 dong) sono serviti in un bello spazio all’aperto che si affaccia sul fiume. Alle ore 18 si può partecipare gratuitamente ad una simpatica cooking class: è stato interessante vedere come si producono in modo artigianale il latte di riso e quello di cocco, che sono poi serviti x preparare insieme il ban xeo. Cosa dire dell’accoglienza? ...ottima! La ragazza che già si era messa in contatto con noi prima della partenza, via email e poi con whatsapp, è stata molto gentile e pronta ad aiutarci in tutto. Anche il resto del personale, pur non parlando inglese, si è dimostrato estremamente cordiale. Avevo chiesto di organizzarci un tour privato per il pomeriggio ed è stato molto gradevole: durante le 3 ore in cui siamo stati in giro abbiamo navigato sul fiume, esplorato a piedi una zona in cui ci sono alcune produzioni artigianali e, su una barca a remi, ci siamo deliziati della tranquillità che regna nei canali secondari.... Il tutto è stato reso ancora più piacevole dalla compagnia di una guida molto valida: un ragazzo del posto (Tan) che parlava un ottimo inglese e che ci ha spiegato molte cose sulle tradizioni locali. (Il tour è costato circa 22€ a testa)....assolutamente da consigliare!!! In definitiva abbiamo trascorso qui solo una notte ma ne porteremo con noi un ottimo ricordo! Se può essere utile, dal punto di vista organizzativo, riporto alcuni costi degli spostamenti da/per Mekong Home: - taxi chiamato con Grab da Saigon a qui: 1086000dong, circa 41€ - taxi per stazione bus x Can Tho (chiamato da Mekong Home): 182000dong - Bus x Can Tho: 70000dong a testa

Title: Wonderful Tranquil Stay
Review: We highly recommend this beautiful tranquil spot on the Mekong River. The rooms are as beautiful as the pictures. Excellent housekeeping and comfortable bed with top notch linens. This is by no means a homestay in the usual sense of the word. The rooms are first class. The way the place is run is highly professional yet casual. It is owned by a family of cousins. The manager, Anh, is ever helpful and speaks English well. Meals are taken in the open air dining room and consist of what the kitchen is cooking that evening, lunches are simple but good. Food is family style cooking and tasty but not ostentatious. We enjoyed it very much. We stayed 5 nights and were not bored. The free bicycles enabled us to take jaunts into the countryside at will and were much appreciated. The boat trip is rather expensive for what it is, and is mainly aimed at those who have not already travelled through the delta as we had. It’s up to you. Anh booked our onward travel by Futa bus, the most comfortable and efficient, with pick up at the guest house. A quick and painless way to get to HCMC. Be sure to stay here to relax before braving the chaos that is HCMC!!

Title: Die freundlichsten Gastwirte Vietnams
Review: Wir haben drei Nächte im Mekong Home verbracht. Die Anlage und die Bungalows sind sehr sauber und gepflegt und der Garten wunderschön mit toller Blumenpracht. Die Besitzer sind die wohl freundlichsten Menschen Vietnams. Scooter oder Fahhradverleih sind kostenlos. Lokales Essen wurde für uns jederzeit frisch und lecker zubereitet. Daher hat uns auch nicht gestört, dass Ben Tre ca. 25 min entfernt liegt. Uns wurde in so vielen Dingen geholfen, von der Organisation eines Transfers (der im übrigen deutlich billiger ist als jedes Taxi oder "Grab") bis hin zum Tagesausflug auf dem Mekong. Die Familie ist super flexibel und macht einem quasi alles möglich. Insgesamt eine absolut tolle Unterkunft. Zum perfekten Glück fehlt eigentlich nur noch ein Pool ;) Als Anmerkung für eine Urlaubsplanung in diesem Gebiet möchte ich noch einen persönlichen Rat geben. Für die meisten Reisenden ist ein Aufenthalt für etwa drei Tage ideal, da die Aktivitäten in diesem Gebiet etwas begrenzt sind. Wir haben eine Tagestour im Mekongdelta gemacht und zwei sehr schöne Fahrradtouren in der tollen Umgebung. Wenn man darüber hinaus aber einfach entspannen möchte, ist man hier genau richtig.

Tất cả mọi thứ bạn nhìn thấy trong bungalow của bạn đã được suy nghĩ và được thực hiện với rất nhiều tình yêu. Nó thực sự là khu bảo tồn của riêng bạn trong thiên đường. Gia đình cũng nấu mỗi bữa ăn ở đây trong một nhà bếp được dọn dẹp sạch sẽ cho bạn và sau khi đi du lịch Việt Nam trong một tuần rưỡi trước khi đến đây, tôi có thể nói thực phẩm ở đây là món ngon nhất mà chúng tôi nếm thử. Mỗi bữa ăn chúng tôi nhận được đều là một bữa tiệc và họ cũng cho phép chúng tôi nấu ăn với họ và cho chúng tôi xem một hoặc hai thủ thuật. Phần đáng kinh ngạc nhất của ngôi nhà này là gia đình xinh đẹp mà chúng tôi đã dành cả ngày với chúng tôi. Những gì họ đã tạo ra ở đây là niềm đam mê của họ và những gì họ đã mơ ước làm. Giấc mơ của họ đã trở thành hiện thực để họ đi lên và vượt ra ngoài để đảm bảo bạn tận hưởng những gì họ đã tạo ra. Toàn bộ khu nghỉ mát này họ đã xây dựng bản thân và nó đã để lại cho chúng tôi không nói nên lời. Ngoài ra, hãy xem gia đình của họ về cuộc sống hàng ngày của họ và tiêu chuẩn công việc của họ sẽ cho bạn thấy niềm đam mê mà họ có cho kỳ nghỉ của họ. Điều gì cũng làm cho trải nghiệm này thú vị hơn nữa là tiếng Anh thông thạo của Ahn đã cho phép chúng tôi ngồi và trò chuyện và nói về văn hóa và ẩm thực Việt Nam. Ngay cả đưa chúng tôi xuống các thị trường với cô ấy để làm việc mua sắm cho khách. Xin vui lòng nếu bạn có thời gian đến và ghé thăm nơi này đẹp, bạn chắc chắn sẽ không hối tiếc!

Review: Homestay situata a poca distanza dal paese ma in una zona assolutamente tranquilla. Ci sono alcuni bungalow ben arredati con bagni e doccia ottimi. Immersi in una vegetazione lussureggiante. I proprietari cordiali invitano anche a cucinare insieme un piatto della cena. Ottima sistemazione. Title: Una bella esperienza
Review: Questo "homestay" è composto da alcuni bungalow immersi in un giardini lussureggiante. La struttura, pur immersa nel verde tropicale è pulita, le stanze sono grandi, con una doccia spartana ma efficiente. I letti sono muniti di un baldacchino con zanzariera. Trovandosi in piena campagna ovviamente durante la notte si sentono i rumori degli animali che comunque non disturbano più di tanto il riposo. Piacevole l’esperienza della lezione di cucina con la famiglia ospitante e qualità dei piatti serviti per cena e colazione decisamente ottima. Ottimo servizio di WiFi. Per gli ospiti sono a disposizione delle biciclette per delle brevi escursioni nella campagna circostante.

Title: Ốc đảo Shady
Review: Chúng tôi đã được đưa đến nơi xinh đẹp này bởi cô San tour Châu Đốc. Thật là một thời gian rất đặc biệt. Cảm ơn bạn Vinh vì sự tận tâm và trải nghiệm cá nhân của mình. Khi chúng tôi đến sau một chuyến đi xe hơi từ HCM, chiếc xe dừng lại trên một con đường mù nơi chúng tôi gặp một chiếc xe máy lấy hành lý của chúng tôi khi chúng tôi đi xuống một con đường làng đến một ốc đảo. Mỗi nhà nghỉ được đặt trong thiên đường xanh với ao, thiết bị nấu ăn truyền thống và cây ăn quả truyền thống. Thức ăn ngon nhất là ở Việt Nam vì chúng tôi được dạy cách chuẩn bị một cách truyền thống với lệnh cấm Xeo xay hỗn hợp gạo của chính chúng ta. Chuối đặc biệt của Vinh với sô cô la kết thúc. Ngày hôm sau, ông sắp xếp cho một chuyến đi thuyền, nơi người lái xe đưa chúng tôi đến nhà và ngôi chùa của ông và chúng tôi cảm thấy được mời vào một trải nghiệm du lịch phi đích thực đích thực. Các căn hộ khép kín của Jardin du Mekong rộng rãi, riêng tư, thoáng mát và đầy đủ tiện nghi. Các phòng nằm giữa khu vườn rộng lớn, râm mát và tươi tốt. Một nơi đẹp và yên tĩnh ở một góc đẹp của đồng bằng.

Title: Lưu trú duyên dáng ở đồng bằng sông Cửu Long
Review: Đối tác của tôi và tôi ở tại Jardin du Mekong trong một đêm và rất muốn giới thiệu nó cho một quan điểm độc đáo về cuộc sống địa phương dọc theo đồng bằng sông Cửu Long. Tài sản thực sự thú vị, với cabin mộc mạc nhưng đẹp mà thoải mái và cung cấp tất cả những điều cơ bản. Thật thoải mái khi ngồi bên ngoài trên xích đu và tận hưởng khung cảnh bên ngoài - có rất nhiều suối, cây cầu và cây cối xung quanh. Vinh đã giúp cung cấp mọi thứ chúng tôi cần, giúp sắp xếp xe buýt của chúng tôi từ Sài Gòn ($ 5 hoặc khoảng 110, 000 VND mỗi xe) và có xe máy tại điểm dừng để đón chúng tôi và đưa chúng tôi đến homestay của mình. Ông cũng sắp xếp cho một chuyến đi thuyền dọc theo đồng bằng sông Cửu Long (khoảng 400, 000 VND) là một cách hoàn hảo để xem khu vực - hướng dẫn của chúng tôi thậm chí đã dẫn chúng tôi đến một ngôi làng địa phương và đưa chúng tôi về nhà của mình cho một dừa tươi ngay từ cây của mình). Bữa ăn tối dồi dào và ngon miệng và thật vui khi được giúp đỡ với một số công đoạn chuẩn bị. Bàn chân ngâm với nước sả nóng là một cách tốt đẹp để kết thúc buổi tối. Sáng hôm sau Vinh cho chúng tôi thấy đường vào thị trấn bằng xe đạp để chúng tôi có thể đi dạo quanh chợ địa phương. Anh ta cũng thích chúng tôi uống cà phê. Những cảm xúc cá nhân và cái nhìn thoáng qua về cuộc sống địa phương (chúng tôi không thấy những khách du lịch khác trong khu vực này) khiến đây là một nơi tuyệt vời để dành một hoặc hai ngày.

Title: De l'authentique
Review: nous sommes restés 2 nuits chez Khanh et Vinh et nous recommandons vivement cette étape. Les bungalows sont spacieux et la literie très confortable. Très jolie décoration. J'avais besoin de travailler un peu et j'ai beaucoup apprécié le jardin calme et fleuri. Tous les repas ont été vraiment délicieux et très variés. Nous avons beaucoup apprécié participer à la confection des banh xeo le premier soir dans la cuisine. une cuisine d'une propreté immaculée. Toute la famille travaille pour le Jardin et ils sont adorables. Nous avons aussi bien profité des vélos et Khanh a même eu la gentillesse de nous accompagner pour une balade. Il est aussi possible de faire de petites balades sur la rivière ou même d'aller au marché de Cai Be en bateau. Le jardin est fleuri et très bien décoré. il est très agréable d'y prendre ses repas. Non seulement le Jardin vous laisse avec un sentiment de toucher à l'authentique car rien n'est forcé ou artificiel mais il y aussi beaucoup de professionnalisme dans la gestion de ce homestay. Il est impossible de repartir déçu du Jardin.....et pourtant nous vivons au Viet Nam depuis plus de 15 ans. Nous partions ensuite vers Tra Vinh et Vinh nous a organisé une voiture et chauffeur très bien et à bon prix. Nous attendons avec impatience d'y retourner. Merci Khanh Vinh et toute la famille pour ce super séjour!

Title: Sympathique
Review: Chambre chez l'habitant dans un bungalow en bois où tout est mis en oeuvre pour passer un bon séjour à la campagne, à faire du vélo, à découvrir la végétation du Vietnam (et plus particulièrement celle du delta du Mékong) et les produits sur le marché du village voisin. L'accueil est sympathique et chaleureux. La participation à la confection d'une partie du dîner est joyeuse.

Title: Très bonne maison d'hôte
Review: Très belle maison d'hôte. Les chambres sont situées dans des bungalows individuels. Cette chambre d'hôte se trouve au milieu de la nature en face d'un canal d'irrigation. Famille très sympathique et au petit soin où vous pourrez cuisiner avec eu les crêpes traditionnelles pour le repas du soir. Possibilité aussi de faire un tour de vélo où vous déambulerez sur des petits sentiers entre les maison. Le propriétaire parle quelques mots de Français, suffisant pour se comprendre. Petit déjeuner copieux et très bon. Petit conseil, n'oubliez pas la bombé anti-moustique si vous ne voulez pas être piqué. Si cela vous en dit vous pourrez même demander un massage des pieds en fin de repas.

Title: Rất khuyên bạn nên ở lại đây!
Review: Chúng tôi đã may mắn đủ để dành một buổi tối ở đây. Chúng tôi đã được tham gia với một cuộc biểu tình nấu ăn gia đình mà chỉ là một trong những điểm nổi bật của buổi tối. Sau bữa tối tuyệt vời, mỗi người chúng tôi đều được mát-xa chân. Sáng hôm sau sau khi ăn sáng, chúng tôi phải đi xe đạp đến chợ. Những khu vườn trên sân vườn thật đẹp. Chúng tôi thực sự có một kỳ nghỉ tốt và gia đình và nhân viên thực sự làm cho niềm vui của chúng tôi ở lại. Thức ăn ngon và phòng rất đẹp.

Title: Một địa điểm tuyệt đẹp
Review: Đây không chỉ là một khu vườn Mekong, đây là một nơi vô cùng quyến rũ. Chúng tôi yêu thích từng khoảnh khắc của nó, đi xe đạp bên cạnh Mekong, biểu diễn nấu ăn, thức ăn ngon (và chúng tôi rất kén chọn), lòng tốt, sự rung cảm rất chân thực, những ngôi nhà cổ kính, những trái cây tuyệt vời, không rõ. Chúng tôi có thể hết lòng giới thiệu nơi này.

Title: Netter gastgeber, gutes essen
Review: Vinh ist ein ganz lieber Gastgeber, der sich unaufdringlich herzlich um seine Gäste bemüht. Er hat bustickets für die an- und Abreise reserviert, eine kostenlose 1stündige Fahrradtour mit uns durch Obstplantagen gemacht (Fahrräder stehen kostenfrei zur Verfügung) und ohne Probleme eine frühere Abreise ermöglicht (wir haben von 3 auf 2 Nächte verkürzt). Zudem hat er eine schöne Bootsfahrt auf dem Mekong organisiert. Halbpension ist super - üppige Portionen und sehr lecker! Die Bungalows sind basic, aber ausreichend, Warmwasser steht zur Verfügung. Einzig die Sitzgelegenheiten in der gesamten Anlage könnten bequemer sein. Meine Nachtruhe war leider durch laute Tiere und karaoke stark gestört, so dass es nach boots- und Fahrradtour durch wunderschöne Landschaft für uns nicht mehr viel zu tun gab und wir weiter zogen. Vielen dank vinh für deine herzliche Gastfreundschaft Philipp und nicole

Title: Que du bonheur

Title: Tốt để ở trong một khu vực địa phương
Review: Đừng ngạc nhiên khi tài xế của bạn dừng lại trên một con đường rải sỏi và bạn được chào đón bởi Ven, người đang ở đó với chiếc xe tay ga của mình để chuyển bạn và hành lý của bạn đến nơi ở yên tĩnh và thanh bình này. Niềm tiếc duy nhất của chúng tôi là chúng tôi không còn ở đó nữa. Kênh của chúng tôi đi đến một tu viện địa phương để tham quan, lớp học nấu ăn và bữa tối tuyệt vời, sau đó là một buổi mát xa chân được thực hiện cho một ngày đầu tiên tốt đẹp. Chúng tôi sử dụng xe đạp miễn phí để đi khoảng 15 phút đến Chợ Lách làng địa phương. Nice khu vực thân thiện mà không phải là ở tất cả các touristy. Hãy thử trải nghiệm delta. Âm thanh ban đêm là kỳ lạ của Đông Nam Á.

Title: Bellissima esperienza
Review: Pochissimi bungalow in un giardino tropicale bellissimo, spazi aperti e privati dove poter gustare i piatti della cucina Vietanamita che voi stessi preparerete nella lezione di cucina organizzata dalla famiglia titolare della homestay. Un’esperienza veramente bella. Biciclette a vostra disposizione per poter girare in libertà l’area circostante. Posizione perfetta per visitare questo tratto del delta del Mekong. Altamente consigliato !

Title: Great local experience
Review: Vinh helped us immensely during our trip; he not only arranged our transport (which was comfortable and hassle free), responded to our texts when we got a bit confused about the bus :), let us take part in a cooking class to make Vietnamese pancakes, arranged a foot massage, let us borrow bikes for free to explore the local area, took us out on the bikes for a cycle into the local town, and showed us around the local market (sampling fruit and snacks along the way). These bonuses weren't added on as a fee as such though we did tip as a thank you. The home stay itself was very comfortable and pretty. There were some creature comforts missing like clean crisp sheets, but otherwise the room was lovely and we enjoyed sitting in the hammock outside listening to the local karaoke wafting towards us. I thought the surprise frog in the bathroom was an added bonus as part of the countryside experience :). The food was lovely too. Mmm breakfast pancakes. I'd recommend this if you're interested in seeing some local life and a bit of a countryside getaway. It seems like you're miles away from anything but if you explore a little you find there's life all around.

Le tout dans un jardin luxuriant bien arrangé. En fin de voyage nous avons apprécié ce relatif confort par rapport aux autres maisons d'hôtes. Nous le recommandons volontiers.

Title: A little slice of heaven
Review: Loved this place. It's a bit far out, and we took about an hour motortaxi ride to get there. Once you get there it's all worth it. If you come from the chaos of Ho Chi Minh, this is a much needed repose! The rooms are quaint and rustic; they've got all you need, including a bed with a mosquito net. We arrived late and Vin had dinner waiting for us, as well as some refreshing juice. Breakfast was also good - delicious local fruits and sweet crepes with iced Vietnamese coffee. Vin took my friend and I on a bike ride through the area, and this was one of the highlights during our one night stay there. Highly recommended for a night.

Title: Great Visit
Review: Vinh was a perfect host. He guided us expertly and easily from Saigon to Ben Tre, and made our stay highly enjoyable. When we arrived at the check-in desk at the public Bus Station in Saigon, the clerk answered the phone and said, "For You" - it was Vinh checking we were OK. When we got off the bus in Ben Tre a couple of motor-cycle taxis were waiting to take us to his home where a chilled and freshly squeezed clementine juice awaited. In the afternoon we took bikes into the local town to explore, read in the hammocks and then ate. The 4 course home-cooked al fresco dinner was excellent, lots of fresh local herbs in addition to being very good value. Great "home-cooking" and one of our favourite meals during our trip. We ground the rice and turmeric for the Banh Xeo in Vinh's grandparent's antique mill, and cooked our own pancakes ahead of the meal. The following day Vinh arranged a private boat for a day-trip which was also good value and fun. As we were leaving he introduced his mother, who had been orchestrating things from inside the house/kitchen, who she gave us some delicious home made vegetable crisps for our journey. Highly recommended.

Title: dépaysement garanti

Title: A proper mekong delta experience
Review: Stayed here for one night during the rainy season. Vinh told us what bus to get from Saigon, and even booked us the tickets in advance. Upon arrival, two people on motorbikes were waiting for us, drove us down a narrow path for 5 minutes to reach the homestay. The place itself is off the beaten track on a small tributary, seemingly quite deep in the jungle. It's a ten minute bicycle ride to the nearest town (with a market, shops, etc.), which Vinh offered to us free of charge, including some rain jackets - which came in handy! As this homestay only includes breakfast and dinner, make sure you load up for lunch before your arrival if necessary, as the location really is remote. The room itself is a little hut just off from the main house, incredibly clean, with a large mosquito net to help protect you from mother nature. Water and tea/coffee are provided, along with towels. The garden surrounding our hut was beautiful, and we sat in the hammock watching chickens and butterflies pass by. The sound of the rain on the roof is amazing. You really do feel a million miles away from everywhere. Dinner was huge, with Vinh very kindly introducing us to his family and how to prepare a traditional Vietnamese dish. Breakfast was equally extensive. Though Vinh 's English was not the strongest, we had few problems communicating with him. He showed us around the area, pointing out the various flora, and also organised our ongoing bus journey, even having his brother sit with us at the bus stop to ensure we got on the right bus. Absolutely outstanding service and beautiful stay.

Title: Cosy home-stay in a romantic tropical setting
Review: Stayed here one night in a bungalow en-suite and enjoyed it very much. The huts are cleverly hidden from each other in a lush garden. The cute bungalow with shower and bucket bath, mosquito net and fan was clean and atmospheric. (Note: We were lucky enough to encounter beautiful big lizards - I don't mean gekkos - and a huge spider inside the bungalow. If you're more intimitated than fascinated by this kind of fauna, you may want to think twice sleeping in a cottage with open space between the wall boards. But then again: we're in the tropics.) Our host Vinh was very reliable organizing just about everything for us with the precision of a German engineer: pick up, cooking class and dinner (with a foot massage as dessert!), bike tour in the orchards and moto taxi to the next place.

Title: Dépaysant et magique à la fois !

Title: True Vietnam Village Experience

Title: Feel like part of the neighbourhood!
Review: My husband, myself and our two young daughters stayed in this home stay for 3 days. After a long drive from HCMC we were met by Vinh, who coordinated that our luggage be taken to the home stay by motorcycle, while he guided us over the narrow paths (only scooter and bicycle traffic here) to the home stay. We were welcomed by two dogs and pretty soon also met Vinhs mother. A few more targeted words: Accommodation - we stayed in 1 out of 7 bungalows. These were built to blend into the garden and were not, and not meant to be, very luxurious. However, it had everything we needed, even a separate toilet and shower, a chest of drawers and a small table and two chairs. There was lots of room and two big beds with mosquito nets. No airco, but a fan and the temperature at night was around 25 degrees Food - OMG, you really can't beat this!! Vinhs mother and sister in law sure know how to cook. And they serve dish after dish after dish, we had to decline dessert, there really was no space left… Language - unfortunately Vinh's English is not so good. It made it difficult for us to learn about the surroundings. Also, it seemed that he was a bit uninterested, but that might be because of the language. Some other guests came over with a fluent French-speaking and English-speaking guide and we were lucky to be able to join the group for a bike ride and a visit to the market where the guide told us many interesting facts. We wish that Vinh could be more pro-active. All in all, we were happy to have stayed here, we really felt like we belonged to the neighborhood (we had a daily walk past all the neighbors (back and forth) and our daughter even became friends with a very cute Vietnamese girl who lent her her bicycle!). We can't think of how to improve the accommodation and the food was really excellent. Now it's up to Vinh to become more engaged.
