Title: A most awesome experience
Review: Ben Che was an interesting and unique town, with its main industry being coconut. What made the whole experience incredible, started and ended with Oasis Hotel. The hotel itself is definitely a quiet oasis from the noise and bustle of the town itself. The common space is communial, yet has enough space and areas for some privacy should you not be feeling social. The pool was perfect for cooling down after a hot day of travel. The owners are both incredibly welcoming and friendly, as are all the staff. Most speak great English and are happy to talk and answer questions but everyone made us feel like we were home. Other than breakfast, Oasis doesn't serve food but there are a few near-by restaurants and even an option for pizza and pasta if you're craving something more western. For breakfast I had the standard omlette and baquette but it was filled with a delicous sauce, which was a unique twist on most uninspired omelette breakfasts you get in Vietnam. The rooms are simple, clean, spacious, and comfortable but other than sleep and change, I didn't spend more than a few minutes in it during my stay. The tours that Oasis leads, give both an understanding of the importance of the coconut industry, and allow you to experience the culture of the region. Overall I would say that Oasis made a possibly mediocre visit to a remote region of the Vietnamese Delta into and brilliantly fascinating, and entertaining experience. I would highly recommend both the hotel and the Ben Tre area.

Title: The magic of a Vietnamese river trip
Review: On the riverfront in Ben Tre, the Oasis Hotel was recommended to me by a friend and I'm so glad I took their advice. I had a poolside room with ensuite. Constant hot water, clean room and comfortable bed. I loved the plastered ceilings! The staff were very friendly and helpful and owners Ken and Lieu made us feel at home, with cooked breakfasts and some evening meals together. We very much enjoyed their trip up the river, which was delightful. Stopped off at some of the businesses along the river -brickworks, coconut processing, tea shop with local musicians, mat-making craft works and a lovely lunch specially arranged. This was one of the highlights of my stay. Also enjoyed the markets, the old style Vietnamese homes on the river which have been newly built as tourist attractions and the interesting restaurants suggested by Ken and Lieu. Wasn't quite prepared for riding round on the back of motorbikes though and had to buy some more appropriate clothing!! I would definitely stay again and recommend it to others. Ken is a Kiwi, so English is spoken.

Title: Great place to explore Ben Tre and the Delta
Review: For 30 USD, rooms are quite modest but comfortable. The kindness of the owners and the manager, as well as the swimming pool and filling free breakfast still provide good value for the price. The owners helped us organize a fun "DIY" boat trip to Tra Vinh by cargo boat. We could borrow a cellphone in case anything happened and we were even offered snacks for free when we learnt that the boat would not stop for lunch as planned initially (to make sure we would catch our bus back on time). Bikes can be rent for 60 000 VND per day and the staff will inform you on the many fun bike rides you can do to explore the surroundings. The town center is about a 5 minutes bike ride away and features a nice market. Last reco, oasis can be hard to reach since the bus station is about 5 km away from the center and often buses from Ho Chi Minh city will drop you even further on random spots along the road, where taxis are scarce. Just contact oasis before getting there and they will give you advice on how to get there without too much hassle. Overall great and fun stay. We would definitely return if we go back to Ben Tre.

Title: My favourite stay in Vietnam
Review: Loved this tiny hotel in the small town of Ben Tre. I can only echo what many other people have said about this charming small hotel run by a friendly couple. Not much to look at when you first arrive, but very soon we were taken in by the chilled out atmosphere and wonderful staff. Rooms were spotlessly clean and ice cold with effective, quiet A/C. A great breakfast was included with superb coffee and eggs, breads etc. Hammocks everywhere throughout their gardens, a small pool to cool off in and bikes and mopeds for rent if needed. Small bar area in the evening a nice place to hang out in for a beer. Ken and his lovely wife Liu (apologies, not sure how spelt!) were the most welcoming helpful hotel hosts I have encountered. Ken went out of his way to set up bike seats for my little daughters, and would do absolutely anything to assist his guests. Liu kindly took us for a visit to a local orphanage that we had asked about, and while there, she acted as translator, guide, and also helped with our transport. We couldn't have done this without her kind help. We didn't go on Hong's highly recommended tour as we had already done similar tours earlier on during our holiday, but she was equally helpful pointing out local restaurants, activities etc. Would love to revisit one day, thanks Ken, Liu, Hong, for a great stay at your hotel! Michael

Title: This place truly is an oasis
Review: My son and I stayed at the oasis for several nights after riding our bikes across the Mekong Delta. What a wonderful place with very helpful friendly owners and staff. A clean refreshing pool was a great respite from the dust and heat. The whole place is very clean , comfortable and a great "home base" for exploring the area. The owner has many suggestions for places to go , things to do. My favorite was the blind massage place - a project of the Norwegian government. They also employ a Vietnamese guide who will take you on a river boat ride to see the area - definitely NOT AT ALL touristy!! They go out of their way for you to have an authentic experience and do not take you anywhere where there are tourists -- they stay strictly off the beaten path! There are bicycles and motorbikes available for your use Delicious breakfast is served daily , drinking water available - also cold beer , somewhat of a rarity in the Mekong Delta. Highly recommend this place - it's wonderful!!

Title: An odd gem
Review: We booked three days in the Oasis and added a fourth, which was generous of Ken and Lieu as the fourth day was Tet and supposed to be their day off. In fact, Ken and Lieu showed us tons of hospitality by helping us with bus issues and even ferrying us about for tickets and such. The hotel has a homey feel so if you want to feel anonymous, this isn't the place for you. The rooms are clean and cheery with surprisingly good mattresses, nice pillows and 100% cotton sheets. Breakfasts are a cut above with one of the best omelettes I've had and the coffee is pleasantly strong. The pool is a bit cool and the tiles a tad slippery so it might not be ideal for kids. Hong, a staffer, was a delight and very good company during a Mekong boat trip she conducted. As an aside, Ken likened the hotel to Fawlty Towers and there is a contingent of eccentric visitors who give the place its odd charm.

Title: Comfortable stay with friendly owners
Review: Two of us stayed overnight at Ben Tre Oasis on the first day of a 4-day trip through the Mekong Delta to Phu Quoc. The hotel is run by a New Zealander, Ken, and his Vietnamese wife, Lieu. The room was comfortable. Bathroom was small and basic, but with plenty of hot water. Wifi good. For $30 each, and at short notice, they organised a 4-hour boat trip for us on the river, taking in a brick factory, a coconut factory and a sweet factory. We also had a 4 course lunch in a homestay and a rowing boat trip through one of the smaller tributaries. Next day, they helped with our onward travel to Vinh Long. A short but pleasant stay with nice hosts.

Title: Freundlich, familiär - und mit Super-Mekong-Tour
Review: Das Oasis Hotel ist ein einfaches, freundliches und warmherziges Haus, dessen große Stärke vor allem in der familiären Atmosphäre zwischen Chefs, Personal und Gästen besteht. Die Zimmer bieten alles, was man für den Preis erwarten darf, inklusive Klimaanlage/AC. Besonders stolz sind Chefin Lieu und ihr neuseeländischer Ehemann Ken auf den angeblich "kältesten Swimmingpool Vietnams" - wirklich erfrischend. Es gibt auch gemütliche Hängematten neben einem kleinen Kasten mit Büchern (zum Ausleihen und Tauschen). Das Hotel liegt nicht im Zentrum von Ben Tre, sondern etwas abseits auf der "falschen" Seite des Flusses. Für alle Aktivitäten braucht man ein Moped (Verleih im Hotel) oder Taxi, was aber nicht teuer ist. Dieser Standortnachteil wird mehr als aufgewogen durch den rührenden Service des Personals, die gemütliche Stimmung an der Bar, wenn Cuu Tho den Gästen seine Michael-Jackson-Interpretationen zum Besten gibt, und die sofortige Hilfe in jeder Situation. Kein Bargeld zur Hand? Schon kutschierte Ken mich persönlich auf dem Moped zum nächsten Automaten. Ken begleitete uns auch zur Stelle, wo wir vom Bus aufgesammelt werden sollten, und wartete dort eine halbe Stunde mit uns. In diesem Hotel wird einem warm ums Herz. Und Ben Tre lohnt sich wegen des tollen Markts und der noch wenig touristischen Innenstadt allemal! Tipp: - Von vielen auf Tripadvisor empfohlen ist die Mekong-Tour des Oasis Hotels - und dies absolut zu Recht. Ein absolutes Highlight der gesamten Reise, wunderbar begleitet von Hong: per Boot, per Fahrrad, inkl. Fahrt durch die Seitenarme des Mekong, Besuch in einer Ziegelei und einer Kokosnuss-Produktion (ohne Kaufzwänge), Essen im "Dschungel" - ein beeindruckender Rundum-Einblick in das Leben am Mekong. Unbedingt buchen!

Title: Excellent hospitality, kind and friendly staff

Extremely friendly and helpful owners and staff members, do rent a scooter and visit the two small islands if you have time: they'll show you the way. But mostly do go on a private boat trip along the river and the small canals: being short on both time and money we couldn't do the $30pp full day tour of the Mekong they offer (it sounded great though) so they arranged a small boat with local guide (who spoke amazing English) to take us on a 3 hour river tour for a very reasonable price instead which was amazing. Definitely a highlight of our trip through SE Asia. After checking out we were going to walk with our luggage to the nearest bus stop to get to the next town but Ken, the owner, insisted on giving us a lift to the station instead (free of charge) so we could get seats before the bus filled up. Very kind people, we will definitely stay here again if we're back in Ben Tre and highly recommend it to anyone else visiting the area it's well worth the price!

Title: Essential Part of any Vietnam Trip
Review: There are probably few hotels in the world that manage to provide a family type stay at a reasonable price in a very clean setting and where the owners are directly involved in making your stay as comfortable as possible. Oasis is such a place. Ken Horsfall is a New Zealander who has led an interesting life and I encourage everyone to buy his book “Life Is an Adventure...If You Choose to Make It So” on Amazon which is what I just did. He takes great care of his guests and the bikes they rent out and even accompanies them into Ben Tre if they need some help, in our case with getting our massage sorted out which by the way is highly recommended. Title: Good value, clean & friendly. Make sure you do the boat trip
Review: Unlike Can Tho, Ben Tre is a distinctly quieter Mekong Delta town and that's one of the best reasons to visits. You won't see hordes of tourists here. And Oasis is a really great place to explore the region from -- something the staff will happily help you do. It's run by a Kiwi guy, Ken, and his Vietnamese wife, Lieu, who are chatty, knowledgeable and warm. They also have an amazing employee Hong who organises superb tours through nearby Mekong villages via boat and bicycle. She speaks superb English and is unflappably friendly. The hotel itself is mid-range, simple but clean. Rooms decent sized, good hot water showers, comfortable beds and TVs. Wifi works well. There's a small pool to cool down if the weather is hot and a nice outdoor area with hammocks for relaxing. Oasis is a little way out of town, on the other side of the river from the main market but I really wouldn't let that put you off. For a start, you have a quiet street and a nice view of the main town from where the hotel is. Plus there are bikes that you can hire to get into town within 10 mins. Behind the hotel is a network of concrete paths and canals that can also be explored on bikes. There's a fantastic local restaurant within walking distance and a newly opened care selling ice cream. Ken or Hong will tell you how to get there. The main reason I came was to see a slice of life in the Mekong and Hong's tour was fantastic. I got lucky, I was the only person staying in the hotel at the time. We took two bikes onto a motorised boat down the main river and then turned into smaller tributaries, stopping along the way at a brick factory, a small coconut factory and a family run mat making business. Nothing felt pressured or faked, these are real factories with real people in them. They're not set up for tourists, but tourists are welcome. The work is hard and Hong doesn't sugar coat it, she shows you what Mekong manual labour looks like and boy does it make you feel lucky. Later we switched to the bikes to explore more of the inland villages for lunch before placing them back on a small paddle boat and then rejoining the bigger motorised one. The whole tour, which was from 8-1pm cost $40 not including tips which felt entirely reasonable. I think if there are bigger groups the price is $30. So if you want a clean, comfortable, affordable stay in Ben Tre that lets you see some of the real Mekong Delta, Oasis is a good recommendation.

Title: My stay at Oasis Ben Tre
Review: The Oasis is a small hotel situated just on the other side of the river from the main town. We caught a taxi from the main bus station expecting a trip of around 1km. (we caught a local very cheap bus from Can Tho.........never again, take the vip bus or an equivalent) The hotel advertises that this is the approx distance from the city centre. The trip was actually around 5 km as the bus station is not near the city centre and my partner was starting to wonder if we were being taken for a ride. This was not the case so don;t worry if you are watching the taxi meter and the km's start to clock up. Once there the owner Ken originally from NZ made us feel very welcome indeed and we immediately started to feel at home. From an English speaking point of view it was a breath of fresh air to be able to communicate clearly with Ken who knows the town and the people very well. Ken is very laid back and to the point, he will sometimes sit there as guests come in and not introduce himself as the owner. Quite the comedian and gentleman he is light hearted and engaging. The tour that is run from his hotel was simply amazing and an experience i will never forget and highly recommend. We had done a few other small tours within Vietnam with extremely friendly and competent guides but i would say this was the better. You can hire motor bikes and cycles or swing the day away in hammocks by the (covered) pool. The Oasis hotel is close to the city centre with a short walk over the bridge, the rooms are clean and with hot water that actually runs hot (unlike most of the hotels we managed to find ourselves in) On a personnel level i would like to thank the staff and especially Ken who went out of his way to ensure I found what i needed in Ben Tre. Putting me on the back of his bike we scoured the city for provisions. Ben Tre is a town with money and it is an up and coming destination. The town markets located under the bridge are a must to visit. Riding no more than 2-3 minutes on a motorbike from the hotel you are in the country with local villages and small local bars. I would return to Ben Tre and the Oasis Hotel in a heart beat. Thank you for a great stay and good luck in the future. Barry (Kiwi) and Michele

Title: Good for a night or 2
Review: We stayed here for 2 nights at the end of a week at various homestays in the Mekong Delta. Basic but well run guesthouse. Couldn't fault the staff, and the NZ owner, Ken, was unbelievablel in helping me organise the cargo boat (a must do - a leisurely 5hrs + on your own either in a hammock or sunbathing on the roof of a 'slow boat to china' cargo vessel from Tra Vinh to Ben Tre or reverse at a mere £5-6 ish pp). Clean rooms with decent linen. Only disappointment was that having ordered a bottle of the local plonk (we had consumed several of the Vinh Delat over the previous week so were well acquainted with it!) we found it to be off/turned (ie. sherry-like). Ken was fine with this and called it a 'croc bottle'. However, his wife/boss wasn't and insisted we either pay for it or at least replace it. We took the latter option and bought a replacement from the supermarket but found the idea that a dud bottle was still chargeable in any form a little distasteful. We were also charged for being rowed across the river (about a 3 min journey) when with other hostels/homestays we have had transfers/collection inc. 10 min + ferrys and then a back-of-a-bike ride for anther 10 mins or a row boat for 25 mins in one case - all for free. Just felt that there was an element of greed which ruined the experience a bit.

Very fresh fish and crabs at very reasonable prices. The hotel half day tour was excellent - boat trip; brick factory; coconut factory; candy factory; lunch with so much food; tuk tuk ride and paddling down a scenic small tributary. Title: truely an oasis
Review: We stayed here for one night only on new year's eve and wished we had booked for longer. Ken and family were away for a short holiday so Hong looked after us. We went on Hong's tour - in fact it was the reason we booked the hotel in the first place having read about Hong's tour on tripadvisor. Both Hong and her tour really lived up to their reputation. Hong took us on a boat trip, showed us a working brick factory (very interesting and you see the bricks everywhere you go in Vietnam), a working coconut production group (boy do they work hard!) a coconut sweet factory (OK) and we had a lunch prepared by a local farmer (really lovely). We felt that we were meeting ordinary people going about their hard daily work, as well as experiencing the tranquility of the river. Hong was extremely knowlegeable and has great values in terms of tourism - that tourists should experience the reality of a country and its people in a way that benefits the tourist and the people. This was a real highlight of our holiday. We also hired bilkes the first day we were there and it was lovely cycling the local countryside with kids calling out hello to us in delight. The two restaurants we were recommended by the staff provided the best real Vietmanese food we had all holiday. We were the only Westeners there and in fact Westerners were not common in this area and people called out Happy New Year to us wherever we went in a friendly way. The comments on tripadvisor that the fabric of the hotel needs attention are right. We felt that for the price the clean rooms and relaxed atmosphere were great but some renovation would enhance the experience. Getting there was also very easy. We took the public bus Thinh Phat company from HCMC to Ben Tre (70,000 dong each way, booked seat and v comfortable) and they dropped us right in the hotel and picked us up again for our return. We highly recommend this hotel. Thanks Hong and staff!

Title: Oasis Hotel a hidden gem
Review: I picked the Oasis on the back of TripAdvisor reviews and I can only endorse what has been said, previously. I stayed two nights and now wish I'd had one more night there and one less in Saigon. Title: The warmest of welcomes
Review: My stay at the Oasis Hotel, Ben Tre was one of the highlights of 6 months on the road. Title: Excellent experience

Title: A unique charm
Review: Basic accommodation but all the necessities are provided and the cost reflects what you get which makes The Oasis really good value for money. What makes it exceptional value is what money cannot buy; just by being themselves everybody here contributed in a positive way to making our too short stay wonderful and relaxed. Booking direct with the hotel was a simple process with emails being replied to promptly and efficiently by either Ken the owner or Hong who also arranged our cars to and from HCMC at better prices than we could find elsewhere. On our first day we rented bicycles from Oasis and did a bit of getting out and about by ourselves. Easy to find your away around and to explore little tracks as the rivers and bridges act as points of reference. On our second day was the 'piece de resistance', Hong took us on a guided tour of their part of the Mekong Delta during which we used a small motorised boat and smaller rowed boat and bicycles. Just travelling around this, as yet, relatively unspoiled part of the world was a delightful, educational and wonderful experience. Visiting a brick factory, coconut sweet making factory and other notable local industries was cream on the cake. While taking lunch at a restaurant during the tour we saw a steady stream of tourists heading past us through the jungle, we asked Hong where they were going, she told us that they were going to a restaurant that is specially for tourists and isn't very good. Our food however was excellent with a number of local dishes and fresh spring rolls made with Elephant ear fish as the main ingredient. All in all the tour was one of the highlights of our time in SE Asia. Recommend you get to visit here before demand from Chinese, Korean and Russian tourism spreads this way and completely ruins Ben Tre, I asked Ken over an evening beer what his plan was when the inevitable occurs, his reply was mostly unprintable. At night we took our bicycles and headed into Ben Tre which is charming yet unremarkable and that in itself makes time spent here worthwhile. The market caters for local consumers with dignified stallholders and as yet is not flooded with overpriced tourist memorabilia. There was very little of interest that we had not already seen elsewhere and nothing in my size but is still worthy of a visit. Not much English is spoken here and my wife thinks that the sight of 6'1", blonde (going grey) Englishman cycling around with a tiger balloon tied to the back of his bike stopping at food stalls and miming what he wanted to eat will live in local memory for a while. In other cities it is probably an every day occurrence but here that is not the case. All in all Ben Tre was a very worthwhile part of our trip and I really wish we had stayed longer here. Oasis hotel is wonderful, welcoming, friendly and excellent value for money.

Title: lovely little spot away from the madding crowds

Title: well-named, well-done!
Review: After spending the previous week in Hanoi and HCMC, I was ready to get away from the noise and stress of the city. Oasis Hotel at Ben Tre turned out to be the perfect choice. It was only 2 1/2 hours and about 75000 dong away by local bus, which leaves something like 7 times a day from HCMC and drops you off right in front of the hotel. While I was there, they were able to arrange a tour for me last minute, even though I was traveling alone. The tour was made to order. I said I wanted a small boat, to see some nice scenery. I left at 8am with Mr. Liem and his dog, and he took us into ever smaller waterways until I had to sit on the floor of the boat because the canopy was so low overhead and the palm fronds brushed both sides of the boat! In the meantime, there was plenty of river life to photograph. We also stopped at a large hut where a group of ladies were sitting on the floor weaving brooms and where Mr. Liem bought some fresh coconut and chopped at it with a hatchet so that we could each have a coconut juice to drink on the boat. It was very pictureseque and exactly what I was hoping to see in the Mekong delta. For only an extra 50000 dong, Mr. Liem also took me on a mini-tour on land afterwards, which included visits to the coconut candy "factory" and brick "factory" as well as a visit to his favorite vegetarian restaurant, which was quite good and cheap. I wasn't all that interested in visiting the factories, especially the brick one, at first. The word "factory" is a bit of a turn-off, as it made me expect something industrial and depressing. But I'm so glad I ended up going, because they are nothing like how westerners think of factories. The coconut candy factory in particular was really just a few workers sitting around a table making everything by hand. It was a great place to buy gifts and souvenirs, as they let me sample everything, and had many homemade coconut-related products for sale, besides the candy. Kiwi Ken, his wife, and the other people I met at the hotel (friends of Ken and other guests) were wonderfully down-to-earth, friendly, and interesting. The vibe by the pristinely clean pool was very relaxing. Comfy hammocks were scattered everywhere. Cold beer was always available. Both pool and hammocks were covered from the sun. It seemed easy to either keep to yourselves, if you wanted privacy, or join Ken & company at the long picnic table in the evening for a bit of socializing and meeting new people, if that's what you were after. It's true that the hotel is not in the center of town, but you can walk across the bridge to a market, some stores, and restaurants in about 10-15 minutes, or to a nice restaurant around the corner in about 5. As others have said, bikes are on loan. And Ken himself was nice enough to offer rides into town on the back of his motorbike. So I didn't find myself at all inconvenienced at any point during my stay. Ah, Oasis Hotel, I miss you already, and I hope to be back soon!

Title: Bia Hoi and three wise men!!!
Review: I always wanted to run a hostel; this hotel is exactly how I imagined it to be. We travelled to Ben Tre form HCMC on a local bus they picked us up from our hotel on xe om’s. Title: Not the Hilton ... A very Good Thing
Review: Before going to the Oasis in Ben Tre, the owner Ken downplayed this charming little hotel in an email to me, telling me not to expect the Hilton. But what this charming little hotel has is everything a chain or large hotel doesn't: mainly that personal touch coupled with a real family and friends atmosphere. The Oasis is owned by an expat Kiwi and his lovely wife Lieu. Staffed with a very friendly group of young workers and located in the heart of the heart of Vietnam, this is the place to stay. The rooms are basic but super clean, there is a pool and there is good cold beer and iced coffee (the included breakfast is good - the Vietnamese coffee is of course superb). There are friends of the hotel that come around, expats from other countries mostly, who are all nice and extremely interesting to talk to. The hotel is also quite family friendly. We rented bicycles each day during our three night stay and traveled the back roads leading in and around the various tiny villages along the river. This province has not been tainted by tourism yet. There isn't a two tier system on prices, for instance, the smiles are genuine and you will be warmly welcomed at every little coffee shop or restaurant you happen to stop at. Indeed, as we pedaled along the little roads and paths we heard innumerable children calling out "hello" as we passed. The hotel also rents motor bikes (the little 125 cc's you see everywhere in Vietnam) which appear to be in good condition. The bicycles could use some work - but bicycles in Vietnam are pretty crummy everywhere. The market in town is easy to get to (just across the bridge) and there is an indoor market catering to Vietnamese with numerous clothes and other shops. Both enjoyable and worth a visit. There is a pretty young woman selling fruit smoothies down on the left outside of an appliance type store, usually with a young girl helping her. Recommended and the folks sitting around her are all fun. If you have any questions or need ideas about what to do or see - just talk to Ken or Lieu or one of the staff. There is lots of information available from them on what to do and where to go. They can arrange local guide trips at reasonable prices or just give great suggestions. There is no pressure here to use their services. We rented their bikes one day and pedaled to an island (with ferry service) for lunch and a cruise around the river. Great time. A local walk to a dinner restaurant that I highly recommended is Mai Vung. Excellent food, spectacular décor and feel, really superb service and very reasonable Vietnamese prices to boot. We went there twice we liked it so much. They actually have two menus – the one in English is shorter and there is a longer mostly, indecipherable one, in Vietnamese (and I had a Vietnamese food guide to help - the excellent "Fat Noodle Guide to Vietnamese Street Food"). After Mai Vung walk further along to the 3D Cafe for some incredible ice cream and very nice servers and atmosphere. The various cafes and street restaurants in and around Ben Tre are all very good as well. There is a bia hoi place (daily fresh beer at about 25 cents a glass) (easy bicycle ride and longer walk) from the Oasis. The Bia Hoi place is highly recommended. Very cheap but very good fresh beer and homemade snacks prepared by the very nice family that runs it. This province of the Mekong and Ben Tre were my personal favorites traveling around Vietnam. Beautiful, lush, great food, wonderful friendly local people, basic amenities and most importantly, few tourists. I wish I was there now having a cold one with Ken.

It was right by the river along a set of loively walking paths that our kids could explore. With the help of a taxi, it was easy to get into and out of Ben Tre Center. We definately recommend this place for people and without kids.

Title: Great hotel with very helpful staff
Review: Ken and his wife are, as the other reviews say, a lovely couple. The hotel has a lovely pool, big rooms with working aircon, and a substantial breakfast. It's a bit of a walk from the centre of Ben Tre, but you can rent bicycles (we did) and it's more a country place than a city place anyway. The boat tour was pretty cheap and worthwhile. There's no restaurant in the hotel, but if you ask nicely the staff can make you a sandwich or something - the restaurant down the road is a bit so-so. Ben Tre is a maze of little alleys and bridges, we got lost for about an hour before we gave up and went back. Still a lot of fun.

On the way back, we caught the sunset and bats feeding on the river! On the whole, it was a memorable trip, and we saw what we wanted at a fair price.

Title: Felt at home at a family run Oasis
Review: The best feature of the place is its people. Lieu and Ken do know how to run the place and make you feel at home. The staff are nice and eager to help you. It is on the river bank road on a quiet side of the river, near Bridge two (between Bridge One and Two.) We stayed in a Twin room on the first floor looking out to the river. Like most place in Vietnam, it's very clean. The room is quite spacy, with a fridge, a tv, an con. Wifi is strong downstairs. Unlike the other side of the river, you feel safe riding on a bicycle, not so much traffic. About 5-6 kilometers away (I think) there's a small local ferry that you and your bicycle can go on crossing to a small island (1,500 Dong - (US$ 0 .60 for both). Riding around the island with small houses and their coconut and pomelo trees is refreshing. On the way back, stop over at a local store, have a beer with ice and buy some fruits- still at a local price. Ten minute walk fro the Oasis will get you to a nice and friendly "3D Cafe" with a really good Wifi. Ice cream, floats, and next door noodle bought to you will see you there for at least an hour or two, just because it is so relaxing. They also do decent French Fries. The young lady running the place is really warm and friendly. We went there by booking a day trip to Mekong tour (US$ 10/person), then get a Mai Linh taxi from My Tho to the hotel (about 400,000 Dongs - US$ 19 with the motor way toll). The driver didn't quite know where it is. Ben Tre is worth a visit, if not for anything else like the canal, sugar cane candy tour etc, it is enough just for relaxing and meeting nice people.

However, we found taxi there is relatively expensive compare to local standard!

Title: Escape the tourist-trap and explore the real Mekong Delta
Review: We have just arrived home after a great 2 weeks traveling around Vietnam. Two nights on the Mekong Delta was our last stop and we were desperate to escape the well-worn tourist path, so we chose Ben Tre and stayed at Oasis Hotel. We arrived late, so Ken quickly showed us to our rooms (we had the choice of one by the pool or a quieter room around the back)- we chose the Pool side room. The room had great aircon, a very comfy bed (not hard like many of the budget hotels in Vietnam) and great shower pressure. Basic but very clean and comfortable. At the price you couldn't ask for more! Ken then gave us a quick overview of the Ben Tre area and set us in the direction of the restaurant around the corner armed with a Torch. The menu was very extensive and we over-ordered but very reasonable prices. The next day we wanted to explore the surrounding villages so Ken set us up with a motorbike and a great explanation of areas to see. It was a fabulous day- not a tourist in site! (Apart from ourselves). No one spoke English and no one tried to sell us anything. We were greeted at every corner with a smile and a big 'Hello!' I would suggest to anyone wanting to venture off the beaten track as we did, having a phone with a GPS map is very very handy. No one in the area will understand Maps (a lot of people are not educated and would never have seen a map before) plus the language barrier makes it difficult if you do get lost. We rode to Ba Tri, another rural town South-East of Ben Tre. From there we followed the water line and hopped on a ferry to one of the tiny islands in the fingers of the Mekong. The island was great- no cars, barely any people or houses-only a narrow concrete and dirt path. We had a ball weaving our way through palm forests. We caught two ferries during the day, the first cost 3000D and the second 5000D (charged per bike, not per person). We then returned to Ben Tre by the main rode. The day trip took us about 6hrs but we had many breaks along the way. On our return, Ken asked my partner if he'd like to join him for a drink at their local waterhouse. Ken is very welcoming and such an interesting character! Our final day we jumped on a halfday tour with two other Aussie ladies. We ate lots of coconut products, listened to some local music and had a great lunch. We traveled by boat and by bikes. During the tour we did see a couple of other large tour groups (8-12 people all traveling together by boat and open-air buses). We went to different places to them that were much quieter, where we four were the only ones there, and I preferred the bike riding down small tracks rather than taking a bus! Back at Oasis, Ken let us shower in our room (even though we had officially checked out) and had a final beer by the pool with him and some of the other guests. Ken and his wife are such warm people and their generosity filters down to their guests- so it is a more communal experience than in other hotels/b&bs. Ken then booked us our bus back home with a free pick up service from the door of the hotel. A great experience! Anyone wanting to stay away from the package tour floating market/overcrowded mass of Can Tho should definitely check out Ben Tre and stay with Ken at Oasis!

Title: Great value for money.
Review: Some of the other reviewers have rated the rooms "sober" - I must be accustomed to more meagre Hotels, because I thought our room was superb. I think we paid around $30 a night, and it was a really comfy bed, nice clean bathroom, spacious room, with a nice big window. Over-all the staff were friendly, though Ken was away, and the chap in charge was friendly in a mildly 'officious' manner. Once you got past that front he was nice enough. The breakfast to me is disappointing as there are no Asian choices. Unfortunately though that seems to be common in Vietnam. Having said that, the omelette was very nice. The coffee was horrendous - but I should have thought of asking for some more hot water. The pool is a great touch, and you are protected from the burning sun by a full roof cover. Unfortunately this makes the water very cold, but I guess you can't have everything! At least you are protected from sunburn! Tips on what to do in the area; Rent the Hotel bicycles and ask them to show you the route to the little ferry that goes across to a tiny island. It's a great experience - we caught the ferry with children on their way to school. Also ride the bicycles into town to the supermarket where you can pick up your supplies. The local Restaurant around the corner from the Oasis has some great meals but avoid the chicken! We had chicken and it was a tough old boiler we could barely chew. We nearly didn't go back there until some other Guests at the Hotel recommended some other dishes, so we went back and had some other really nice meals including clams in ginger, and huge shrimp. For dinner we went to Chuon Chuon Restaurant which I can't speak highly enough of. The menu is all in Vietnamese so ask at the Oasis to write down what sort of meals you'd like before you go. You can ride a bicycle there or catch a taxi. The food is outstanding. The Hotel will arrange tours for you if you ask but we chose just to wander the town and relax. It's a great place for that. The locals don't see huge numbers of tourists so they often smile and say hello! So we will definitely return to the Oasis in the future to unwind and enjoy the slower pace!

Title: Want a hotel where you are treated like family
Review: Spent 7 nights at the Oasis Hotel in Ben Tre. As an American I was there during the war and speak Vietnamese. I am hoping to return again since Ben Tre is very interesting place and take my 2 daughters back with me.

Title: A home away from home
Review: This quaint little guesthouse is located on the quiet side of the river, close to paths for bicycling and walking, near an excellent restaurant recommended by Ken, the owner, and tucked in enough amongst the coconut trees to give you some breathing room. There is a little pool that feels so refreshing after a day on a junk boat in the Mekong, and Ken and his staff have worked really hard to put together an authentic traveling experience to avoid the constant flow of tourist buses that are otherwise all over the Mekong Delta. The hotel staff was amazingly kind and helpful. Just say the word, and the staff is there trying to provide. They even tried to arrange for me to visit the hospital in town to see the labor unit as I work as a labor RN in the states. Phoung, the owner's son, spent time with us poolside with a cold beer, offered us insight into life in Vietnam, in Ben Tre, in the Mekong Delta. On our last day, they took us to the local market to buy prawns and then cooked them up for us, along with a huge lunch that we shared before boarding the local bus back to Saigon which they arranged for us. The only thing I can think to advise people about is that no one is going to come in your room and pick up after you. Personally, I was perfectly happy finding my room the way I left it; it always seems strange to me to make someone else responsible for cleaning up after me. If you aren't into keeping your room neat, either deal with it, or stay at the other places that will not nearly give you the same personable attention. The ONLY reason I bring this up is because some people might get bent out of shape about stuff like that, and I would hate to see the genuine customer care and regard be replaced by seemingly insignificant details due to complaints. Please don't ruin it for everyone else. We absolutely loved staying at the Oasis Hotel, and wish Ken and his incredibly kind family the best; they absolutely deserve it.

Title: Highlight of our trip
Review: We had a superb time at the Oasis. Check out the hotel website for contact details: they’ll gladly provide you with any info you’re after, and you also arrange a room booking.  We’d been travelling in Vietnam for three weeks prior to arriving, and this was by far the highlight of our trip; not only because it’s a beautiful place, but because the owner (Ken) and his family made us feel so welcome. As previous reviewers have already said: the hotel is in a great location (on the quieter, more rural southern shore of the river); the rooms are bright, clean, and air conditioned; the common area (with bar and pool) is fun to hang around in; and – in particular – Ken, his family, and staff are fantastic. As for many before us, we were reluctant to leave and extended our stay to four nights. While there, we stuck around Ben Tre (beautiful tributaries and canals lined with tropical forest and rural homes), and Ken provided us with (great) advice on where to go. If you want to do your own thing you can set off on foot, on push bikes, or on motor scooters; if you want to do a tour there’re are a range of options. Also, this is a good place to make plans (again, advise is available is available if you want it) and then head deeper into the Delta. For food, the hotel has a simple but tasty breakfast menu and snacks available during the day. There’s a good restaurant right around the corner with an English menu, and a few places across the river. Getting there from HCMC is a breeze (get in touch with the hotel for help planning). One option is to jump on a Mai Linh minibus in HCMC (you’ll probably need to change buses at the bus station on the edge of town, but the driver takes you to the right bus); when you get to Ben Tre, if you tell them where you’re going, they put you in another bus and drop you right at the front door of the hotel. All-in-all, we highly recommend the Oasis hotel. We hope to return someday!

Title: Amazing experience
Review: This place is absolutely amazing, and i would wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone who wants to see the Mekong Delta "off the beaten track". Thai arranged tours for us (at additional cost) which were a great way to see the local area, and with very engaging tour guides - ask for Huong's love story and language lessons! Thai is currently developing some new accommodation right on the Mekong river, which could be spectacular once completed. If you're looking for a luxury hotel, then this isn't the place for you. Bạn có thể thư giãn trong khu vườn tuyệt vời hoặc hoạt động theo ý muốn. Các phòng đều thoải mái - chúng tôi vẫn ở trong phòng gia đình. Ông Thái là một người có kinh nghiệm, sự ấm áp và tầm nhìn, những người có thể giao tiếp bằng tiếng Anh khá tốt. Anh ấy là một nhà tổ chức tuyệt vời và thật dễ dàng để đến đó và anh ấy đã giúp chúng tôi chuyển đến Cần Thơ.

Title: Can not recommend
Review: Of all the homestay experiences I have had in the Mekong Delta, this is the only one I would never return to. The common practice of the homestay owner is to send his employee to nab unsuspecting travelers when they step off the bus and take them to his homestay. We actually had a reservation at a completely different place, but his motorbike "nabber" waylaid us and even posed as the guy we were meant to stay with. We trusted him and only started to suspect that we had been tricked when we were charged almost double what we had agreed to at the original place. They would not let us leave and insisted we join the boat tour (which was a series of stops at tourist trap gardens and honey farms - not the usual pleasant boat ride in Mekong backwater). Our friends drove down from Saigon to rescue us, but still were not able to get back the full amount of money we were overcharge. Mr Thai runs a dis-honest business and is a poor representation of the usually kind and generous people of the Mekong Delta. As a long-time resident of Vietnam, I was doubly disappointed to read the reviews of how many other unsuspecting travelers he has duped. Stay away!

Title: Secret homestay in authentical Mekong Delta
Review: We wanted to enjoy the Mekong Delta the authentic and non-touristic way and we could not wish for anything better! We had to take the early bus from Ho Chi Minh City to Ben Tre where we were picked up by scooter drivers who brought us to the lonely homestay of Thai. It was paradise! In the middle of his little garden full of mango and papaya trees he welcomed us with a cool coconut drink! After showing us our cozy bungalow on the water, an ealderly neighbour picked us up for a bicycle ride through the wunderful Mekong Delta!he explained us in english what every plant was and what the people use it for. We were invited to drink a tea at his house where he teached us some vietnamese words. After a great homemade lunch at the homestay we were picked up for a private boat trip through the narrow water canals and visited Turtle Island. During the little trip we were invited to try so many different and interesting fruits of the Delta region -just delicious!!We also visited a coconut candy manufacture before watching the sunset from the boat. It was just the perfect tour to get a real impression of the land and people of the Mekong Delta! In the evening we had a wonderful dinner prepared by Thai's wife. Though we were not hungry after all the fruit tasting, we had to try everything!it was delicious! The second day, we were picked up after an early breakfast to go on a scooter tour. The guides where very friendly and spoke very good english.they took us to real local markets where foreigners had never been seen before(!) and again we were invited to try all the food. We visited farms and rice fields as well as a very local spot where we had very good vietnamese lunch. Last stop was XY where a private boat would take us to the floating markets!our guide explained everything so good that we learned so much and I think we will remember that day for very,very long!! The bus ride back to Ho Chi Minh was organized by Thai so that we did not need to care about anything. It was a real highlight of our trip through Vietnam!!probably the most authentic experience!

Title: Peaceful Garden in the Delta
Review: I really enjoyed speaking with Thai about the projects he's undertaken for the good of his neighbors and community; he really cares about his home and the people he shares it with. Thai's wife (I apologize for forgetting names) was all too generous as a chef, and the food (and local produce) was by far the best I had over the course of five days in the delta. It was perhaps a bit difficult to speak to anyone but Thai himself in English, but it's all the more reason to learn a few words of Vietnamese, and I can't say I hold it against the family for maintaining living spaces apart from the guest's areas. What interactions I was able to have with the rest of the family were all very positive. Free use of the bicycles was fabulous, and I had my best experiences in Ben Tre by bike. Be sure to explore. My only complaint would be that you need to do some checks on the bikes before you take your pick. Most of them are in disrepair in one way or another, so be sure to test each. The beds and bathrooms don't compare to nicer hostels or hotels, but I didn't expect them to. They were adequate; fans were amply available, and you'll want to spend your time outside the rooms anyway; lounging in a hammock or simply sitting in the peaceful garden. A final word with regards to getting references to tours and hotels from locals: I think it's usual for family and friends to send customers each other's way, so simply take recommendations with a grain of salt; they will seldom be objective. I did not book a tour through Thai, but then I only discovered him through one of his friends in My Tho. I also didn't take him up on his recommendation for another hotel in Can Tho (which was my onward destination). I've found it not uncommon to get conflicting recommendations about a place from different people in Vietnam: one local in Can Tho steered me away from Thai's recommended hotel with some negative comments about it. I don't mean to accuse anybody of anything - just be aware that there's often a conflict of interest with references from locals.

Title: Basic accommodation but well worth it for the tours!
Review: We stayed at Mr Thai's home for two nights and had a great time. His house is far from any tourist areas and only accessible from Ben Tre centre by bike/motorbike. His house & grounds are quiet and relaxing. Rooms are very basic - no aircon and very hard beds but we had expected this from other reviews. There is also no mirrors in the rooms and the sink is communal outside by the pond. Food that was cooked was simple but tasty (cooked fish from the pond, rice, veggies, fruit). We also had some interesting food we'd not tried before! When you stay at Mr Thai's, he will arrange tours for you. As we only had a couple of days this suited us. We would recommend a tour with Hoa (an older gentlemen) who was really friendly, knowledgeable and has an interesting life story - we did a boat tour and a nature walk and was probably the best day of our two week holiday. Another day, a tour was arranged where we went to the rice fields (beware: very muddy!!) and Cai Be floating market. In the 2 days we saw a lot of the area and learned a lot about the Mekong Delta life. The cost for both tours was $60 each which we thought was good value for money. 2 days at Mr Thai's was ideal for us and personally wouldn't stay longer due to the basic accommodation.

Title: Mr Thai's Homestay
Review: I travelled with friends to Vietnam on a motorcycle trip around the Mekong Delta. One of the stop overs was at the home of Mr Thai. We had been warned that the Vietnamese homestay beds were hard, but that didn't quite prepare us for how hard they actually are :) Our host, Mr Thai was a wonderful man who entertained us with the story of his life and prepared us a delicious and memorable meal of fresh Elephant Ear Fish caught from his pond. Title: For tours, ask for Mr. Y (pronounced 'Eee' in english)
Review: We had 4 nights at Mr. Thai's place a couple of week's ago - we really enjoyed the peace and quiet and after 3 weeks in other areas of Vietnam, it was nice to experience life out of the main tracks. As in other reviews, Thuy's (Mr. Thai's wife) cooking was great, and we enjoyed the breakfasts, fruits, lunch (when we were there) and dinners - including the fish caught in the home pond. As you can see in the photos, accommodation and amenities are basic - so make sure you're going for the experience. Regarding the tours, take your time now (before you go) to consider what other recent reviewers have said in terms of pricing etc. Know that you'll be out in the country and Mr. Thai's tours are the most convenient (as one reviewer said, how else are you going to do any?), and take your time going through the arrangements with him when you arrive and start discussing options and prices. Our initial tour with the older gent was a little rushed as it was later in the afternoon when we arrived, raining a bit and dusk was approaching. But it was great to walk the little tracks, experience the boat ride and the fireflies, and ask about his experiences during and post the american war. The next day we had a huge tour of all the fruit farms, 3 islands and ferries, animal market, small floating market and more. Mr. Thai drove one bike and his colleague Mr. Y drove the other, both great ... I noticed my wife chatting non-stop with Mr. Y the whole day - GREAT english, and a great conversationalist, sharing all sorts of information and everyday stuff. So definitely ask for him as a guide!!! The next day we went with Mr. Y and Thai's young brother-in-law (who was pretty quiet and doesn't speak english) to the Khmer area of the Mekong and the Khmer Buddhist temples and monasteries around Tra Vinh area. Again another huge day out, heaps of impressions to process, great lunch along the way, Mr. Y awesome and chatted with my wife again the entire day. The next day, Mr. Thai had arranged a car, driver and the older gent to take us out to the coastal area of the Mekong and sites along the way - it didn't work out so well as he got lost, we didn't get to the coast ... On our last morning, we had a great breakfast, packed up and were dropped off at the bus back to HoChiMinh by Mr. Thai ready to get our flight home. He also organised a few purchases for me including packaged coffee beans which was much appreciated. As in all these experiences, ask for what you want/need ... and yoou may need to negotiate a bit - overall very helpful.

Title: Probably the best place in the beautiful Ben Tre
Review: This place is the only place you need to stay if you are visiting Ben Tre or My Tho. We actually had plans to stay at Mango riverside prior to reaching Vietnam. But due to the attitude of the staff and extremely late replies to emails, we cancelled our booking and a quick searching in the web took us to this wonderful place. Initially we were skeptical about this place since the photos were not that attractive. But I blindly trusted all the positive reviews and booked. And it turned out to be much higher than our expectations. First of all no other place in Mekong delta can match the charm and beauty of the pristine Ben Tre. It has almost zero foreigners and the land is so fertile that you find fruit orchards and other trees everywhere. The vegetation is so dense here which I have never seen in other parts of Vietnam. Secondly, Mr. Thai is such an awesome person. We were surprised when we came to know that the lady at Thinh Phat bus booking office in Saigon district 5 told that she knows this person. She called Mr. Thai to inform about our arrival. And he was there waiting for us. He and another person took us in motorbike (for free) to his house which is a 15 minute ride. That 15 minute we were awestruck by the beauty of Ben Tre. Even his house is surrounded by a lot of trees with fruits in it. It also has a small pond where you can fish. Thai gave us enough fruits during our stay and we also had the freedom to pluck whatever we need. The best part is, he arranged another great man, who was our boating trip guide. I highly recommend you to take at least one of the boat trip or the motor bike trip. We had time only for the boat ride. And the 74 year old man who was our guide was the best guide we ever had in Vietnam. It was almost a 6 hour trip and he took us to the most awesome places in Ben Tre. The best part was the coconut candy place where we were served plates full of mangoes, jackfruit, papaya, sapota and the most delicious honey tea. They also let us taste snake wine. He also took us to several villages and we really enjoyed the charm that Ben Tre is. Around 7pm before the trip ended, he even took us to a place where there is a tree full of fireflies. It looked just like a christmas tree. While leaving this place, Thai even gave us a few mangoes and one big dragon fruit. It was really tough to leave this place. Thank you Mr. Thai for the wonderful stay. If ever there is a place in Vietnam we will visit again, this will be the first in our list.

Title: Fantastic overall, not for everybody.

Title: Lovely family, great food, relaxed location

Title: It was a pleasure

Title: Ruhige Lage
Review: Das Homestay befindet sich ca. 5 bis 6 km vom Zentrum entfernt. Strassenverkehr ist am Abend keiner wahrzunehmen. Da es sich in der Wohnzone der Einheimischen befindet, muss man mit Karaoke am Abend leben. Es hört gegen Mitternacht auf. Der Gastgeber stellt gegen ein Entgelt von 50‘000 VND / Tag ein Fahrrad zur Verfügung. Es ist ideal um die nähere Umgebung zu erkunden. Die Verrechnung finde ich jedoch nicht in Ordnung. Wir waren in Unterkünften welche die Fahrräder auf Grund ihrer Lage kostenlos zur Verfügung stellten. Die Zimmer sind geräumig und in einem guten Zustand. Einen Zimmerservice wie in einem Hotel gibt es nicht. Du machst dein Bett selber und wenn das WC-Papier aufgebraucht ist musst du es melden. Zum Frühstück gibts ein Baguette, 2 Spiegeleier und Tee. Kaffee oder andere Speisen werden wiederum zusätzlich in Rechnung gestellt. Auf Wunsch servieren sie ein Nachtessen. Für 150`000 VND erhält man 1 Vorspeise, 2 Hauptgerichte und 1 Dessert. Die Qualität vom Essen ist wirklich gut. Der Preis geht für das Gebotene in Ordnung. Bezahlt wird am Schluss vom Aufenthalt in Cash. Mit Cash meine ich VND. Das „Mann“ US$ wechseln kann ist noch nicht bis hierher vorgedrungen. Wir mussten auf Grund vom Wochenende welches wir hier verbrachten den ATM bemühen obwohl wir US$ dabei hatten. Es ist Schade dass dies nirgends bei der Buchung vermerkt ist. Bei booking.com heisst es nur vor Ort bezahlen. Ich kann das Homestay auf Grund der Lage und den vielen zu bezahlenden Extras nur bedingt empfehlen. Wäre alles klar ersichtlich aufgeführt gewesen, wäre ich nicht hier gelandet.

Nhà trọ cách Bến Tre khoảng mười phút lái xe, vì vậy chúng tôi đã ăn ở đó cả buổi tối và có những bữa ăn cực kỳ ngon miệng, được nấu bởi mẹ ông Kha Điều. Thực sự, món ăn ngon nhất kể từ khi ở Việt Nam. Họ có xe đạp cho thuê ở mức 50, 000 vnd một ngày và vùng nông thôn xung quanh là nơi hoàn hảo để khám phá với tốc độ nhàn nhã trên hai bánh xe. Mr Kha rất đáng yêu, hoàn toàn cam kết đảm bảo khách sẽ cảm thấy thoải mái và hài lòng. Điều này hoàn toàn trái ngược với một khách sạn vô danh hoặc một nhà trọ chật chội, vì vậy đừng để khoảng cách từ thị trấn đưa bạn đến - ở Bến Tre, đó là vùng nông thôn và sự thân thiện của những người bạn đến, không có gì trong thị trấn mà phân biệt nó Lưu ý rằng dịch vụ TV rất hạn chế nhưng ai muốn dành thời gian xem tivi ở một nơi như thế này?

Đây là: tất cả những điều trên, cộng với, siêu thanh trên cao nhìn ra sông Bến Tre, hồ bơi sạch sẽ, lựa chọn lớn các món ăn sáng Việt Nam / phương Tây nấu chín, nhân viên thực sự hữu ích, quán cà phê và nhà hàng gần đó, dễ dàng đi dạo 15 phút sông vào thị trấn. Điều gì không nên yêu cho AU $ 36. 00 một đêm! ! ! !

Title: Rat khuyen khich
Review: Chúng tôi ở đây 5 ngày và mỗi ngày thật hoàn hảo, giá trị thực sự tuyệt vời, hồ bơi nhỏ sạch đẹp đủ lớn để làm vòng, bữa sáng tuyệt vời, internet nhanh, truyền hình cáp, dịch vụ phòng được thực hiện trong khi chúng tôi đang ở bữa sáng. Rất khuyến khích là Phạm Thị Quế Hương trong buổi tiếp tân, cô ấy đã giúp đỡ chúng tôi rất nhiều, luôn mỉm cười và lịch sự, cô ấy đã đặt chỗ khởi hành của chúng tôi, cũng như lụa. Cảm ơn bạn!

Title: Lựa chọn tuyệt vời trên sông, đi bộ đến thị trấn
Review: Chúng tôi đặt Phòng Deluxe trên tầng 2 nhìn ra sông, sẽ tốt hơn khi lên cao hơn. Nice để thức dậy với những âm thanh của thuyền chugging lên sông. Phòng rộng rãi với bàn và ghế riêng biệt. Giường lớn, rất chắc chắn và một giấc ngủ ngon tuyệt vời. Phòng tắm là kích thước hợp lý tắm trên bồn tắm. Vị trí của khách sạn khá tốt không ở trung tâm nhưng không xa, dễ đi bộ. Rất gần với các nhà hàng nổi mà là một lựa chọn tốt cho bữa ăn tối, giá tốt và thực phẩm chất lượng tốt Khách sạn có một quán cà phê / quán cà phê tuyệt vời / thanh trên tầng thượng, với quan điểm nổi bật của sông và khu vực xung quanh, quan điểm tốt nhất trong thị trấn, diện tích lớn, giá cả cực kỳ thoải mái và hợp lý. Thậm chí sẽ tốt hơn nếu họ đã phục vụ các bữa tối hoặc đồ ăn nhẹ. Tất cả các nhân viên trong khách sạn vô cùng thân thiện và hiệu quả, đặc biệt là các cô gái ở lễ tân là một người thích thú. Sảnh đợi rộng rãi và nhân viên trợ giúp đặc biệt đã đưa ra những hướng dẫn rất tốt cho người Việt Nam về nơi chúng tôi đang đi và không bao giờ có vấn đề gì ngay cả khi chúng tôi có kế hoạch dừng lại! Sẽ đánh giá cao!

Title: Kein Wohlfühlhotel
Review: Auf unserer Rundreise durch das Mekong Delta hatte wir eine Nacht in diesem Hotel. Erster Eindruck beim Betreten des Zimmers - eine große Kakerlake flüchtete über das Bett. Dann wurde uns ein anders Zimmer zugeteilt - zum Fluß und damit zur Hauptstraße hin. Nachts war Nightmarket und so laut, dass man trotz geschlossenem Fenster nicht schlafen konnte. Das Frühstück war rein chinesischer Natur und die vorwiegend chinesischen Gäste fielen darüber her - für Europäer teilweise sehr unappetitlich, aber das kennen wir ja. Service - nicht erkennbar und sehr zurückhaltend. Auf unserer dreiwöchigen Rundreise das schlechteste Hotel, abgewrackt und ohne jeglichen "da fühlen wir uns wohl"-Charakter. Leider nicht zu empfehlen....

Title: All boxes ticked or atmosphere, you choose!!
Review: ON PAPER this hotel ticks all the boxes. Rooms are large & clean, appliances all work, a/c quiet, rooftop bar, conference facilities, banquet room, pool, large breakfast area. Staff are polite, distant & seemingly efficient. There's a security motorbike carpark. It's apparently a 3star rated hotel, I know the room rate was very reasonable. There's a list of the fines you will incur if you break the hotel's rules, including vomiting ( for real! check the photos). Buffet breakfast was barely adequate. Many dishes had run out by 8am, a couple got replenished. The eggs both omlette & fried were leathery even when fresh. Coffee was run out, only 1 juice; evil looking green swamp water tasting stuff. Reasonable selection of asian food, the pho sat premade & you ladled in your own stock. 1 fruit choice. Maybe we've been spoiled at other hotels with freshness, quality & quantity. If you're into the streetfood scene there's some decent ones immediately to the left as you walk out the front gate. We enjoyed a fun night at Lamen ( no english spoken) eating with the locals. And the night markets extend from the city out to the front of the hotel if you don't feel like the 10 min walk into town. That's the positives & if you're a business travellor or someone who just wants all the boxes ticked you'll love it. In reality the place is HUGE compared to most hotels. The public spaces are vast with monumental furniture set up to receive guests for coffee. But no-one was around. We saw the odd guest but never more than 1 at a time & they seemed to be forever scurrying into their rooms. Our voices echoed eerily down wide empty marble corridors as we wandered lost on the various floors. Our room was on the 4th floor but the lift doesn't REALLY go to the 4th floor rooms, you also have to go up a staircase & along a corridor. If you get the staircase wrong you end up on the 5th. Then you have to find a different staircase to take you back to the REAL 4th floor or the lift on the 5th back to the dummy 4th and try again. Made me feel like I was at Hogwarts, or worse, Hotel California! We know the governmental system here is different from ours but until now we never felt its presence. Perhaps this hotel had a previous use (east german embassy?) & being a hotel doesn't sit comfortably, maybe it was the lack of guests, or just our imagination. But I prefer my hotels to have some life & atmosphere about them as well as clean sheets.

Title: OK if nothing else
Review: The hotel is in front of the river with a nice views. There is a lot of street food options very close and one large boat restaurant but nothing else easy to reach by foot. The hotel seems to be managed by the Vietnamese administration with a very confusing list of rules and service pricing document, also displayed in each elevator. For instance, it mentions that customers will be charged 50,000 VND per hour and per person for the swimming pool! We decided to use it but were not charged... not sure why. The rooms and common areas are very clean but with limited (low quality) furniture. We had 4 bedrooms and the safety box in 3 of them were not functioning. There is a fridge in each room but when we arrived in the evening, the fridge in each room was turned off and the drinks were on the desk. Obviously, no one wants a warm soda and we did not find any ice machine. Finally the beds are extremely hard so it is like sleeping on the floor. To finish on a positive note, there is a nice coffee & cocktail bar on a terrasse, definitively the best part of this hotel.

Title: Well worth the money
Review: Very convenient hotel with well kept facilities. Beautiful surroundings in the town of Ben Tre and in the delta around. I suggest you rent bikes (the hotel has bikes to offer for 20.000 VND/hour) and explore the delta on your own rather than buying a very expensive (200-300.000 VND) and humiliatingly touristy boat trip. The town is know for their coconut candy and you can visit a coconut candy factory in town, you don't need the boat trip! The hotel is very nice and staff are very helpful and flexible (they let us check in earlier without us noticing before)! Breakfast is mostly Vietnamese with white toast and marmalade as a Western option. I would definately recommend this hotel to others, I would come back if I went to Ben Tre again!

Title: Riverside Hotel

Title: Very good
Review: Advice for tourists getting to Ben Tre/Ham Luong: to get there from HCMC, use Thinh Phat bus company. Their buses depart frequently and you can just turn up a short while before you'd like to depart. the bus has wifi and free water. upon arrival in ben tre, you get off the bus and a mini-van is waiting, and they will take you to your hotel(very much appreciated). Have the hotel name/address written in vietnamese for this, for ease. The rooftop coffee bar is my favorite thing about this hotel. You can sit, drink a smoothie, and watch over the ben tre river as boats pass by. Extremely serene, especially when it's raining (there's a glass ceiling at the bar.) The rooms (and indeed the hallways and bathrooms) are very big, and my room had a balcony and large window overlooking ben tre. The wifi worked well here (occasionally went down but that happens most hotels sometimes). The staff were polite and efficient and even booked me onto a bus back to HCMC and arranged for me to be picked up directly from the hotel, which was immensely helpful.

Title: Reasonably happy with this hotel
Review: Our family of 11 booked three rooms at Ham Luong for a two-night stay in March 2016. We were all pleased with the quality and comfort of the hotel rooms. The furniture and finishes are a bit dated but very functional. The buffet breakfast was excellent with a variety of Vietnamese and Western offerings. The pool looked quite clean though we did not use it. We enjoyed Vietnamese coffee on the rooftop patio one evening. The view of the river from here was pleasant. I did notice a cockroach in the cafe and one in a side hall on the main floor but did not find any in the rooms. Overall, a good experience given the reasonable nightly rates. I would book again.

Title: 3 star rooms and service at 1 star prices

The buffet breakfast is really good, with loads of choice, both Vietnamese and Western foods. The hotel was very busy when we stayed, but if anything showed signs of running out, more was brought quickly. The swimming pool was lovely for a refreshing dip and there is also a fitness centre. The hotel has bicycles for hire, including 3 free hours of use per room per day. The roof top cafe overlooking the river has great views and reasonably priced drinks. The price was great too, for what you get - a lot! - its a real bargain.

Title: Friendly hotel by the river
Review: Great views of the river traffic from the balcony and rooftop restaurant. Get a room with a balcony overlooking the river. A non western Vietnamese hotel mainly frequented by business people but there were very few foreign visitors in Ben Tre when we were there. The rooms are large and clean and the staff very helpful. Breakfast is included. Fully Vietnamese but fried eggs and bread were available. Get there early when it opens at 6. The tea and food runs out quite quickly after 7. It's a great opportunity to try real Vietnamese food. We hired bikes, which were reasonable half suspension MTBs for a small charge. Definitely recommend: hey were invaluable for exploring the area. Medium sized pool with four loungers perfect for cooling off after a hot cycle ride.

Title: bien dans l'ensemble
Review: Ambiance USSR dans le design de cet établissement. Chambre supérieure sans fenêtre (ou plus précisément vue sur le mur intérieur à quelques m), mais spacieuse et bien équipée, bien que pas des plus actuel. Pas de lampe de chevet, ambiance plafonnier. Pression et eau bien chaude dans la salle de bain un peu vieillotte. Tout est très propre. Petit dej style asiatique et de qualité moyenne comme indiqué dans d'autres commentaires. Mais pain de mie et baguette sont présents quand même. Personnel du desk anglophone très serviable. Nous avons bénéficié de la loc des vélos gratuits via booking.com, les vtt proposés sont de très bonne qualité. Il y a 2 tandems. Piscine agréable, même si l'environnement n'est pas aménagé. Un peu éloigné du centre, 15 minutes à pieds, mais promenade le long de la rivière et marché de nuit. Nous avons payé 27$ la nuit pour la supérieure. Bon séjour dans l'ensemble, mais le 4/5 aurait été un peu excessif...

Title: Decent value but a bit dull
Review: We stayed at this simple hotel for 1 night as a start to our Mekong Delta tour and at ~£18 for a large and clean double room, this represents decent value. There's a bar/roof terrace on the 4th floor that offers a nice view of the river and serves cold, cheap beer. That said, the hotel does lack in atmosphere and you shouldn't expect much in the way of great service. For example, we specifically asked for a quiet room away from the bar area on the 4th floor, so considered it a surprise to be given a room overlooking it (despite the hotel not being full). The front desk staff will be as helpful as they can without actually doing anything, e.g. tell you about bus times but unable to ring and book you a seat OR radio a taxi but cannot advise how much it will cost or how long it will take to the bus station. It has a gym, which was closed whilst we were there and a swimming pool without sunbeds. The breakfast (incl. in price) was mediocre.

Title: Nice hotel, however very rude staff and poor service
Review: I have used this hotel many times as a tourist and do not have anything good to say about the staff or service here. The rooms are nice and clean and the tour service is also good value. However the staff are awful. First of all we had a problem checking in. They refused to accept our booking and told us the hotel was full. This wasn't true and after a long time waiting they finally approved of our agoda booking and let us check in. The swimming pool is nice but the pool chairs are broken, and we have used the pool several times and the reception staff are always changing the price, making it more expensive each time! The restaurant staff are also poor, its difficult to get there attention, the service is slow and once the food arrives its not great and much more expensive than other restaurants nearby. The cafe bar upstairs has a similiar problem with staff being very slow and they usually start closing up the bar before people have finished their drinks. I would highly recommend avoiding this hotel. The staff are a serious let down for the area and it would be a shame if the towns impression was ruined because of the experience some guests might have at this hotel.

We where thirsty, so went towards them and ordered another drink, which came some acceptable minutes later. But after that we were treated with such blatant arrogance that we had to get up again even to pay. It is acceptable if a bar is not ready to service and tells you so. But to sit there thirsty and get ignored by four staff people is just inacceptable. Never again, sorry.
